\'\'\'Emmylou Harris\'\'\' (born April 2, 1947) is an American singer and songwriter. She has released many popular albums and singles over the course of her career, and as of 2015 she has won 13 [[Grammy award|Grammys]] as well as numerous other awards.

Her work and recordings include work as a solo artist, bandleader, an interpreter of other composers\' works and as a singer-songwriter, and a backing vocalist and duet partner. She has worked with numerous leading artists including [[Gram Parsons]], [[John Denver]], [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Dolly Parton]], [[Roy Orbison]], [[The Band]], [[Mark Knopfler]], [[Delbert McClinton]], [[Guy Clark]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]], [[Rodney Crowell]], [[John Prine]], [[Neil Young]], and [[Steve Earle]], and [[Ryan Adams]].<!-- The preceding is not a laundry list. Please be judicious in making additions. -->

==Biography==

=== Early years ===
Harris is from a [[Military brat (US subculture)|career military family]]. Her father, Walter Harris, was a military officer and her mother Eugenia was a wartime military wife. Her father, a member of the [[Marine Corps]], was reported missing in action in [[Korea]] in 1952 and spent ten months as a prisoner of war. Born in [[Birmingham, Alabama]], Harris spent her childhood in [[North Carolina]] and [[Woodbridge, Virginia]], where she graduated from [[Gar-Field Senior High School]] as class [[valedictorian]]. She won a drama scholarship to the [[University of North Carolina at Greensboro]], where she began to study music seriously, learning to play the songs of [[Pete Seeger]], [[Bob Dylan]] and [[Joan Baez]] on guitar.  She dropped out of college to pursue her musical aspirations, and moved to New York City, working as a waitress to support herself while performing folk songs in [[Greenwich Village]] [[coffeehouse]]s during the folkie boom.<ref name = "People-Arrington-1982-11-15"/> She married fellow songwriter Tom Slocum in 1969 and recorded her first album, \'\'[[Gliding Bird]]\'\'.  Harris and Slocum soon divorced, and Harris and her newborn daughter Hallie moved in with her parents in the [[Maryland]] suburbs near Washington, D.C.<ref name = "People-Arrington-1982-11-15"/><ref>"Charlie Rose Show" June 25, 2008</ref>

=== With Gram Parsons ===
{{BLP sources section|date=December 2012}}

Harris soon returned to performing as part of a trio with Gerry Mule and Tom Guidera. In 1971, members of the [[country rock]] group [[the Flying Burrito Brothers]] saw her perform; former [[The Byrds|Byrds]] member [[Chris Hillman]] had taken over the band after the departure of founder [[Gram Parsons]], was impressed by Harris, and briefly considered asking her to join the Flying Burrito Brothers. Instead, Hillman recommended her to Parsons, who was looking for a female vocalist to collaborate with on his first solo album, \'\'[[GP (album)|GP]]\'\'. Harris toured as a member of Parsons\'s band, The Fallen Angels in 1973, and the two of them shone during vocal harmonies and duets. Later that year, Parsons and Harris worked on a studio album, \'\'[[Grievous Angel]]\'\'. Parsons died in his motel room near what is now [[Joshua Tree National Park]] on September 19, 1973 from an accidental overdose of drugs and alcohol. Parsons\' \'\'Grievous Angel\'\' was released [[List of works published posthumously|posthumously]] in 1974, and three more tracks from his sessions with Harris were included on another posthumous Parsons album, \'\'[[Sleepless Nights (Gram Parsons album)|Sleepless Nights]]\'\', in 1976. There was one more album of recorded material from that period that was packaged with the name, \'\'[[Live 1973]]\'\', but was not released until 1982.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}<!-- sources for entire paragraph needed-->

Parsons offered Harris a study in country music, introducing her to [[the Louvin Brothers]], and provided her with a musical identity. Harris\' harmony and duet vocals, on the other hand, were lauded by those who heard them, and helped inspire Parsons\' performances. His death left her devastated at an emotional and musical crossroads. She eventually carried on with her own version of Parsons\' musical vision, and was instrumental in bringing attention to his achievements. Harris\'s earliest signature song, "[[Boulder to Birmingham]]", written shortly after Parsons\'s death, showed the depth of her shock and pain at losing Parsons. It was, according to best friend [[Linda Ronstadt]], the beginning of a "lifetime effort to process what had happened", and was the first of many songs written and/or performed by Harris about her life with (and without) Parsons.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}} <!-- sources for entire paragraph needed-->

===The Hot Band===

[[File:JamesBurton(by Scott Dudelson).jpg|thumb|left|200px|Hot Band member [[James Burton]]]]
[[Warner Brothers]] A&R representative Mary Martin introduced Harris to Canadian producer [[Brian Ahern (producer)|Brian Ahern]], who produced her [[major label]] debut album, \'\'[[Pieces of the Sky]]\'\', released in 1975 on [[Reprise Records]]. The album was surprisingly eclectic, especially by [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]] standards, including [[cover versions]] of [[the Beatles]]\' "[[For No One]]", [[Merle Haggard]]\'s "Tonight the Bottle Let Me Down" and [[the Louvin Brothers]]\' "[[If I Could Only Win Your Love]]".  It also featured "Bluebird Wine", a composition by young [[Texas]] songwriter [[Rodney Crowell]], who was the first in a long line of songwriters whose talents Harris has championed.  The record was one of the most expensive country records produced at the time, featuring the talents of [[James Burton]], [[Glen Hardin]], [[Ron Tutt]], [[Ray Pohlman]], and [[Bill Payne]], as well as two tracks ("Before Believing" and "Queen of the Silver Dollar") that were cut with the Angel Band. Two singles were released: "Too Far Gone", which initially charted at No.&nbsp;73 (a 1979 reissue hit No.&nbsp;13), and Harris\'s first big hit, "If I Could Only Win Your Love", a duet with [[Herb Pedersen]] (later a founding member of [[the Desert Rose Band]]), which peaked at No.&nbsp;4.

Executives of [[Warner Bros. Records]] (Reprise Records\'s parent company) told Harris they would agree to record her if she would "get a hot band". Harris did so, enlisting guitarist [[James Burton]] and pianist [[Glen Hardin]], both of whom had played with [[Elvis Presley]] as well as Parsons. Burton was a renowned guitarist, starting in [[Ricky Nelson]]\'s band in the 1950s, and Hardin had been a member of [[the Crickets]]. Other Hot Band members were drummer John Ware, [[pedal steel]] guitarist Hank DeVito, and bassist [[Emory Gordy, Jr.]], with whom Harris had worked while performing with Parsons.  Singer-songwriter [[Rodney Crowell|Crowell]] was enlisted as a rhythm guitarist and duet partner.<ref name="Hot Band">{{cite web|url=http://www.emmylou.net/hotband.html |title=The Hot Band |publisher=Emmylou.net |date=April 3, 1975 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> Harris\'s first tour schedule originally dovetailed around Presley\'s, owing to Burton and Hardin\'s continuing commitments to Presley\'s band. The Hot Band lived up to its name, with most of the members moving on with fresh talent replacing them as they continued on to solo careers of their own.

\'\'[[Elite Hotel]]\'\', released in December 1975, established that the buzz created by \'\'Pieces of the Sky\'\' was well-founded.  Unusual for country albums at the time, which largely revolved around a hit single, Harris\'s albums borrowed their approach from the album-oriented rock market. In terms of quality and artistic merit, tracks like "Sin City", "Wheels", and "Till I Gain Control Again", which weren\'t singles, easily stood against tracks like "[[Together Again (Buck Owens song)|Together Again]]", "[[Sweet Dreams (Don Gibson song)|Sweet Dreams]]", and "One of These Days", which were.  While \'\'Elite Hotel\'\' was a No.&nbsp;1 country album, the album did sufficiently well as a crossover success with the rock audience.  Harris appealed to those who normally disapproved of the country market\'s pull toward crossover pop singles ("Together Again" and "Sweet Dreams" both topped the country charts).  \'\'Elite Hotel\'\' won a [[Grammy]] in 1976 for [[Best Country Vocal Performance, Female]].

Harris\'s reputation for guest work continued.  Aside from contributing to albums by [[Linda Ronstadt]], [[Guy Clark]] and [[Neil Young]], Harris was tapped by [[Bob Dylan]] to perform on his \'\'[[Desire (Bob Dylan album)|Desire]]\'\' album.  Harris also filmed one of the studio sequences, owing to her touring schedule, in [[the Band]]\'s \'\'[[The Last Waltz]]\'\', singing "Evangeline".

Burton left the Hot Band in 1976, choosing to remain with Elvis Presley\'s band, and was replaced by English guitarist [[Albert Lee]].  Harris\'s commercial apex was \'\'[[Luxury Liner (album)|Luxury Liner]]\'\', released in 1977, which remains one of her definitive records.  On \'\'Luxury Liner\'\', Harris\'s mix of songs from [[Chuck Berry]] ("(You Never Can Tell) C\'est La Vie"), [[Gram Parsons]] (the title track and "She"), [[the Carter Family]] ("Hello Stranger") and [[Kitty Wells]] ("[[Making Believe]]") illustrate a continuity and artistic merit to country music often overlooked at the time. Even so, many fans expected more original tunes, so she became known as a cover artist.  Despite Top Ten singles with "C\'est La Vie" and "Making Believe", the album\'s best known track is the first recorded cover of [[Townes Van Zandt]]\'s classic "[[Pancho & Lefty]]", which would be a No.&nbsp;1 hit for [[Willie Nelson]] and [[Merle Haggard]] in 1983.  At the end of 1977, Crowell left the Hot Band to pursue a solo career; his replacement was [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] multi-instrumentalist and singer [[Ricky Skaggs]].

\'\'[[Quarter Moon in a Ten Cent Town]]\'\' signaled a slight change of direction from Harris\'s previous three albums.  Rather than mixing classic and contemporary, the album is made up largely of recently written songs, though from a wide variety of writers.  "Two More Bottles of Wine", written by [[Delbert McClinton]], became Harris\'s third No.&nbsp;1 single, "[[To Daddy]]", written by [[Dolly Parton]], went to No.&nbsp;3, and a third single, "Easy From Now On", went Top Twenty.  The album included two songs apiece from Crowell ("I Ain\'t Living Long Like This" and "Leaving Louisiana in the Broad Daylight") and songwriter [[Jesse Winchester]] ("Defying Gravity" and "My Songbird"), and [[Utah Phillips]]\' "Green Rolling Hills".

===The Roots records===
In January 1977, Harris married Brian Ahern.<ref name = "People-Arrington-1982-11-15">
{{cite news | url = http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20083549,00.html  | date = November 15, 1982  | issue = Vol. 18 No. 20 | title = Singer Emmylou Harris and Producer Brian Ahern Make (and Record) Beautiful Music Together | first = Carl  | last = Arrington | work = People Magazine  | accessdate = August 7, 2013  }}</ref> 
Their (Harris\'s second and also Ahern\'s second) daughter, Meghann, was born in 1979.  During this period, Harris recorded and released three studio albums that reflected a shift toward traditional country (during a time that the public was beginning to embrace a more polished \'\'[[Urban Cowboy]]\'\' sound).  The roots direction was prominent in her [[Grammy Award]]-winning 1979 album \'\'[[Blue Kentucky Girl (Emmylou Harris album)|Blue Kentucky Girl]]\'\'.  Apart from a cover of [[the Drifters]]\' "[[Save The Last Dance For Me]]", the album was largely made up of classic-styled country material in the vein of [[Loretta Lynn]] and [[Kitty Wells]].  One of her best-loved albums, it includes songs from [[the Louvin Brothers]]\' "Everytime You Leave", [[Willie Nelson]]\'s "Sister\'s Coming Home" and [[Gram Parson]]\'s signature "Hickory Wind".  [[Wesley Rose]] took special interest in Harris\' recording of "Beneath Still Waters", which became a No.&nbsp;1 hit.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

A Christmas album, \'\'[[Light of the Stable (album)|Light of the Stable]]\'\', was released in 1979; its title track featured backing vocals by [[Dolly Parton]], [[Linda Ronstadt]] and [[Neil Young]], all three of whom Harris had worked with sporadically since the mid-1970s, and with whom she continued to collaborate with through the 2000s. (Harris, Parton and Ronstadt began working on a trio album during this time, though it remained unfinished for nearly a decade; a few of the tracks recorded for the project were released on the women\'s respective solo albums in the interim.) The album is largely acoustic, featuring readings of traditional fare such as "Silent Night", "O Little Town of Bethlehem" and "The First Noel".{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}<!-- sources for entire paragraph needed-->

In the 1980s, Harris explored country music\'s history further with the [[bluegrass music|bluegrass]]-oriented recording of \'\'[[Roses in the Snow]]\'\', featuring [[Ricky Skaggs]], [[Tony Rice]], [[Albert Lee]], [[Emory Gordy Jr.]] and [[Jerry Douglas (musician)|Jerry Douglas]].  Harris\'s versions of the traditional "[[The Wayfaring Stranger (song)|Wayfaring Stranger]]" and [[Paul Simon]]\'s "[[The Boxer]]" were strong singles.{{citation needed|date=September 2013}}<!-- sources for entire paragraph needed-->

In 1980, Harris recorded "That Lovin\' You Feelin\' Again" with [[Roy Orbison]].  The duet\'s recordings was a Top-10 hit on both the Country and Adult Contemporary charts. They were awarded a [[Grammy Award|Grammy]] for [[Best Country Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group]].  She was featured on [[Paul Kennerley]]\'s concept album \'\'[[The Legend of Jesse James]]\'\', which also featured [[Levon Helm]] of [[the Band]] and [[Johnny Cash]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}<!-- sources for entire paragraph needed-->

===Pop-chart success, songwriting===
In 1981, Harris\'s recordings reached the Top 40 on the [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] [[Billboard Hot 100|pop chart]] with a cover of "[[Mister Sandman]]"\xe2\x80\x94again Top 10 Country as well as Adult Contemporary\xe2\x80\x94from her \'\'[[Evangeline (Emmylou Harris album)|Evangeline]]\'\' album. (The album version of the song was a track from the  \'\'Trio\'\' sessions with [[Dolly Parton]] and [[Linda Ronstadt]], but neither Parton\'s nor Ronstadt\'s [[Record industry|record companies]] would allow their artists\' vocals to be used on the single, so Harris re-recorded the song, singing all three parts for the [[Single (music)|single release]] of the song.){{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

Harris moved to [[Nashville]] in 1982. \'\'[[White Shoes]]\'\' in 1983 included an eclectic pairing of the rockish reading of "[[Diamonds Are a Girl\'s Best Friend]]" with a remake of the [[Donna Summer]] hit "On the Radio", as well as tracks from a diverse group of songwriters including Hot Band member Crowell, [[Sandy Denny]] and [[T-Bone Burnett]]. It was her last album produced by Brian Ahern until \'\'[[All I Intended to Be]]\'\' in 2008.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

Harris\'s major-label releases thus far included few of her own songs, but in 1985 her songwriting skills were prominent with the release of a concept album \'\'[[The Ballad of Sally Rose]]\'\', for which she co-wrote all of the songs. The album was semi-autobiographical, based loosely on her relationship with Parsons. Harris described it as a "country opera", and a "huge commercial disaster".<ref>
{{cite web |url=http://exclaim.ca/Features/Questionnaire/emmylou_harris |  author=Keast, James |  work=Exclaim.ca | date = June 2008 | title= Questionnaire: Emmylou Harris | accessdate=May 14, 2011}}</ref> 
Her co-writer and producer on the album, English songwriter and musician [[Paul Kennerley]], the writer of the hit singles "Born to Run" (on Harris\'s 1981 \'\'[[Cimarron (Emmylou Harris album)|Cimarron]]\'\' album) and "In My Dreams" (on \'\'White Shoes\'\'). Kennerley also produced her next album, \'\'[[Thirteen (Emmylou Harris album)|Thirteen]]\'\'. They married in 1985 and divorced in 1993.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

In 1987, nearly a full decade after their first attempt, Harris teamed up with Dolly Parton and Linda Ronstadt for a long-promised and long-anticipated \'\'[[Trio (Dolly Parton, Linda Ronstadt and Emmylou Harris album)|Trio]]\'\' disc.  The album was the biggest commercial success of Harris\'s career, spending five weeks at No.&nbsp;1 on Billboard\'s Country Albums chart (also quickly reaching the Top 10 on the Pop Albums chart). It sold several million copies and produced four Top 10 Country hits, including "[[To Know Him Is To Love Him]]", which hit No.&nbsp;1. The recording was nominated for the coveted [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year|Album of the Year]] Grammy award (given to [[U2]] that year for \'\'[[The Joshua Tree]]\'\') and the three women won the statuette for Best Country Vocal Performance by a Duo or Group with Vocal; the album\'s [[Linda Thompson (singer)|Linda Thompson]]-penned track "[[Telling Me Lies]]" reached No.&nbsp;3 Country, No.&nbsp;25 Adult Contemporary, and was nominated for a Grammy as 1987\'s [[Best Country Song]].{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

Harris also released a solo album in 1987, \'\'[[Angel Band (album)|Angel Band]]\'\', featuring traditional [[Gospel music|gospel songs]], on which she worked with then rising country star [[Vince Gill]], and others.  In 1989, she recorded two songs with the [[Nitty Gritty Dirt Band]] on their album, \'\'[[Will the Circle Be Unbroken: Volume II]]\'\'. In a snippet of studio chatter included on one of the tracks, she talked during the recording session about her beginnings and how music had changed:{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

{{quote|Years ago I had the experience of sitting around in a living room with a bunch of people and singing and playing, and it was like a spiritual experience, it was wonderful. And I decided then that was what I was going to do with my life was play music, do music. In the making of records, I think over the years we\'ve all gotten a little too technical, a little too hung up on getting things perfect. We\'ve lost the living room. The living room has gone out of the music, but today I feel like we got it back.}}

1989\'s \'\'[[Bluebird (album)|Bluebird]]\'\' album, which featured contributions from [[Marty Stuart]], [[Bonnie Raitt]], and [[Kate and Anna McGarrigle]], included the singles "[[Heartbreak Hill (song)|Heartbreak Hill]]", which reached No.&nbsp;8 on the U.S. country singles chart, and "[[Heaven Only Knows (Emmylou Harris song)|Heaven Only Knows]]", which reached No.&nbsp;16, the most recent top-twenty chart singles of Harris\' career.  The following year\'s \'\'[[Brand New Dance]]\'\' album received favorable reviews, but marked the beginning of a chart and airplay decline for Harris.{{citation needed|date=August 2013}}

Around 1991, she dissolved The Hot Band and formed a new band of acoustic musicians\xe2\x80\x94[[Sam Bush]] on fiddle, mandolin and vocals, [[Roy Huskey, Jr.]] on bass and vocals, Larry Atamanuik on drums, [[Al Perkins]] on banjo, guitar, [[Dobro]] guitar and vocals, and [[Jon Randall]] on guitar, mandolin and vocals\xe2\x80\x94which she named The Nash Ramblers. They recorded a [[Grammy Award]]-winning [[At the Ryman|live album]] in 1992 at the [[Ryman Auditorium]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], which led to the $8 million restoration of the facility into a premium concert and event venue. It was her last album with [[Reprise Records]].  She has been a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] since 1992.<ref>
{{cite web  | title = EmmyLou Harris | url = http://www.opry.com/artists/h/Harris_Emmylou.html | publisher = Grand Ole Opry | date =  | accessdate = June 29, 2012}}</ref><ref>
{{cite web | title = Opry Member List PDF | url = http://www.opry.com/img/Opry%20Members%20List.pdf| date = April 23, 2012 | accessdate = June 29, 2012}}</ref>

===New directions===
<!--  Commented out: [[File:NeilYoungHeartOfGoldfilmsti.jpg|right|thumb|250px|Emmylou Harris, left, performing with Neil and Pegi Young in \'\'Neil Young: Heart of Gold\'\'.]] -->
By the 1990s, Harris started receiving less airplay as mainstream country stations began shifting their focus to the youth-oriented "new country" format. As with \'\'Brand New Dance\'\', 1993\'s \'\'[[Cowgirl\'s Prayer]]\'\'\xe2\x80\x94Harris\' first studio album after her switch to [[Elektra Records]]\xe2\x80\x94was critically praised but received very little airplay,<ref name="Cromelin1996">{{cite web|author=Cromelin, Richard |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1996-04-11/entertainment/ca-57283_1_emmylou-harris |title=Q & A with EMMYLOU HARRIS: Singing With a Voice That\'s Always True to Her Heart |date=April 11, 1996 |accessdate=May 14, 2011 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref> and its lead single, "High Powered Love" charted very low, peaking at No.&nbsp;63, prompting her to shift her career in a new direction.

In 1995, Harris released one of the most critically acclaimed albums of the decade, \'\'[[Wrecking Ball (Emmylou Harris album)|Wrecking Ball]]\'\', produced by [[Daniel Lanois]], best known for his work with [[U2]], [[Peter Gabriel]] and [[Bob Dylan]]. An experimental album for Harris, the record included Harris\'s rendition of the [[Neil Young]]-penned title track (Young himself provided guest vocals on two of the album\'s songs), [[Steve Earle]]\'s "Goodbye", [[Julie Miller]]\'s "All My Tears", [[Jimi Hendrix]]\'s "May This Be Love", [[Kate and Anna McGarrigle]]\'s "Goin\' Back to Harlan" and [[Gillian Welch]]\'s "Orphan Girl". U2\'s [[Larry Mullen, Jr.]] showed up to play drums for the project.  The album received virtually no country airplay whatsoever, but did bring Harris to the attention of [[alternative rock]] listeners, many of whom had never listened to her music before.

Harris then took her \'\'Wrecking Ball\'\' material on the road, releasing the live \'\'[[Spyboy (album)|Spyboy]]\'\' in 1998, backed with a [[power trio]] comprising Nashville producer, songwriter and guitarist [[Buddy Miller]] and [[New Orleans]] musicians, drummer [[Brady Blade]] and bassist-vocalist-percussionist Daryl Johnson. In addition to performing songs from \'\'Wrecking Ball\'\', the album updated many of Harris\'s career hits, including "Boulder to Birmingham".

Also in 1998, she appeared prominently on [[Willie Nelson]]\'s moody, instrumentally sparse \'\'[[Teatro (Willie Nelson album)|Teatro]]\'\' album, produced by \'\'Wrecking Ball\'\' producer Lanois.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1998/sep/05/entertainment/ca-19591 |title=Willie Nelson, "Teatro," Island. |author=Cromelin, Richard |date=September 5, 1998 |accessdate=May 15, 2011 |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]}}</ref>

During the summer of 1997 and 1998, Harris joined [[Sarah McLachlan]]\'s all-woman musical touring festival, the [[Lilith Fair]], where new artists like [[Patty Griffin]] could share new experiences and ideas with seasoned musicians like Harris and [[Bonnie Raitt]].

In January 1999, Harris released \'\'[[Trio 2 (album)|Trio 2]]\'\' with Parton and Ronstadt. Much of the album had actually been recorded in 1994, but remained unreleased for nearly five years because of record label and personnel disputes, conflicting schedules, and career priorities of the three artists. \'\'Trio 2\'\' was much more contemporary-sounding than its predecessor and was certified Gold. It included their version of Neil Young\'s classic "After The Gold Rush", which became a popular music video and won another Grammy\xe2\x80\x94this one for [[Best Country Collaboration with Vocals]]. Harris and Ronstadt then released a duet album, \'\'[[Western Wall: The Tucson Sessions]]\'\', later the same year.  The two superstars toured together during the fall months in support of the disc. Both albums made the Top 10 of Billboard\'s Country Albums chart and did well on the pop side as well.

Also in 1999, Harris paid tribute to her former singing partner [[Gram Parsons]] by co-executive producing \'\'[[Return of the Grievous Angel: A Tribute to Gram Parsons]]\'\', an album that gathered together more than a dozen artists. Harris performed duets with [[Beck]], [[Sheryl Crow]] and [[the Pretenders]] on this album\'s tracks.

In 2000, Harris released her solo follow-up to \'\'Wrecking Ball\'\', \'\'[[Red Dirt Girl]]\'\', produced by Lanois prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9 [[Malcolm Burn]]. For the first time since \'\'[[The Ballad of Sally Rose]]\'\', the album contained a number of Harris\'s own compositions. Like \'\'Wrecking Ball\'\', the album\'s sound leaned more toward alternative rock than country. Nevertheless it reached No.&nbsp;5 on Billboard\'s Country Albums chart as well as a healthy No.&nbsp;54 on the pop side.  It also won Harris another of her 12 Grammy awards, in the category of [[Best Contemporary Folk Album]].

Harris also accompanied on [[alternative country]] singer [[Ryan Adams]]\' solo debut \'\'[[Heartbreaker (Ryan Adams album)|Heartbreaker]]\'\' and on [[Tracy Chapman]]\'s fifth album \'\'[[Telling Stories]]\'\'.

Also in 2000, Harris joined an all-star group of traditional [[country music|country]], [[folk music|folk]] and [[blues]] artists for the [[T-Bone Burnett]]-produced [[O Brother, Where Art Thou? (soundtrack)|soundtrack]] to the [[Coen Brothers]] film, \'\'[[O Brother, Where Art Thou?]]\'\'  The soundtrack won multiple [[Country Music Association|CMA]], [[Academy of Country Music|ACM]] and Grammy awards. A documentary/[[concert film]], \'\'[[Down from the Mountain]]\'\', featured the artists performing music from the film and other songs at the [[Ryman Auditorium]]. Harris and many of the same artists took their show on the road for the Down from the Mountain Tour in 2002. In 2003, Harris supplied the finishing touches in harmonizing with the [[Dixie Chicks]] on a song they were recording in the studio, "Godspeed".

===Recent work===
Harris released \'\'[[Stumble into Grace]]\'\', her follow-up to \'\'[[Red Dirt Girl]]\'\', in 2003. Like its predecessor, it contained mostly self-penned material. In 2004, Harris led the [[Sweet Harmony Traveling Revue]] tour with [[Gillian Welch]], [[David Rawlings]], [[Buddy Miller]] and [[Patty Griffin]]. They performed singly and together and swapped instruments.

On September 9, 2005, Harris participated in "[[Shelter from the Storm: A Concert for the Gulf Coast]]", a series of concerts [[simulcast]] by most American television stations to raise money for victims of [[Hurricane Katrina]] and [[Hurricane Rita]]. She performed with [[Beth Neilsen Chapman]] and the Dixie Chicks, harmonizing on Patty Griffin\'s song, "Mary". She also lent her voice to the soundtrack of the critically acclaimed 2005 film, \'\'[[Brokeback Mountain]]\'\', on the song "A Love That Will Never Grow Old", which was controversially omitted from Oscar consideration due to an insubstantial amount of time of the song played during the film.

[[File:Emmylou Harris 2006 2.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Harris playing in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] (2006)]]
In 2005, Harris worked with [[Conor Oberst]] on [[Bright Eyes (band)|Bright Eyes]]\' release, \'\'[[I\'m Wide Awake, It\'s Morning]]\'\', performing backup vocals on three tracks. In July, she joined [[Elvis Costello]] on several dates of his US tour, performing alongside Costello and his band on several numbers each night. Harris and Costello recorded a version of Costello\'s song, "The Scarlet Tide", from the soundtrack of the movie \'\'[[Cold Mountain (film)|Cold Mountain]]\'\'. July also saw the release of \'\'[[The Very Best of Emmylou Harris: Heartaches & Highways]]\'\', a single-disc retrospective of Harris\'s career, on the [[Rhino Entertainment]] label. This same year, Harris appeared as a guest vocalist on [[Neil Young]]\'s widely acclaimed \'\'[[Prairie Wind (album)|Prairie Wind]]\'\'. She also appeared in the [[Jonathan Demme]] documentary-concert film \'\'[[Neil Young: Heart of Gold]]\'\', released in 2006.
[[File:Mark Knopfler and Emmylou Harris.jpg|thumb|left|220px|Harris performing with [[Mark Knopfler]], in the Netherlands]]
\'\'[[All the Roadrunning]]\'\', an album of collaborations with former [[Dire Straits]] frontman [[Mark Knopfler]], was released in April 2006 and supported by a tour of Europe and the US. The album was a commercial success, reaching No.&nbsp;8 in the UK and No.&nbsp;17 in the US. Selections recorded during the \'\'All the Roadrunning\'\' tour performance at the [[Gibson Amphitheatre]] were released as a CD/DVD package titled \'\'[[Real Live Roadrunning]]\'\' in November 2006.  In addition to several of the compositions that Harris and Knopfler recorded together in the studio, \'\'Real Live Roadrunning\'\' features solo hits from both members of the duo, as well as a few classic tracks from Knopfler\'s days with Dire Straits.

Harris is featured on \'\'A Tribute To [[Joni Mitchell]]\'\', released on April 24, 2007. Harris covered the song "The Magdalene Laundries" (originally on Mitchell\'s 1994 album, \'\'[[Turbulent Indigo]]\'\'). She sang "Another Pot O\' Tea" with [[Anne Murray]] on Murray\'s album \'\'[[Anne Murray Duets: Friends and Legends]]\'\', released November 13, 2007, in Canada and January 15, 2008, in the U.S.

Harris wrote a song called "In Rodanthe" for the 2008 film \'\'Nights in Rodanthe\'\'.

A solo album, \'\'[[All I Intended to Be]]\'\', was released on June 10, 2008, to critical acclaim.  It reached Top Five of \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\'\'s Country Albums chart and the Top 20 of the Pop Albums chart. Contributors include [[Buddy Miller]], [[Kate and Anna McGarrigle|the McGarrigle sisters]], [[Vince Gill]], [[Phil Madeira]], and her \'Trio\' sister [[Dolly Parton]]. She toured with an ensemble she dubbed the Red Dirt Boys, featuring [[Phil Madeira]] on accordion, guitar, and keyboards, [[Colin Linden]] on guitar and banjo, [[Rickie Simpkins]] on mandolin and fiddle, [[Chris Donohue]] on bass, and [[Bryan Owings]] on drums.<ref>{{cite web |author=Varga, George |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20080731/news_1w31emmylou.html |title=\'I\'m a storyteller\' |date=July 31, 2008 |accessdate=May 14, 2011}}</ref> It did not include Miller, who was touring with [[Robert Plant]], [[Alison Krauss]] and [[T Bone Burnett]] at the time. In 2009, Harris toured with Patty Griffin, [[Shawn Colvin]], and Miller as "Three Girls and Their Buddy". Madeira, Simpkins, and Donohue performed with her in late 2008, and in 2009, appearing on "[[A Prairie Home Companion]]" and at [[MerleFest]] and the [[Telluride Bluegrass Festival]].  In September 2009, Owings rejoined the Red Dirt Boys with Miller for the remainder of 2009.

In April 2009 Harris became a grandmother. Her daughter gave birth to a daughter, Prudence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nashvillegab.com/2009/10/all-for-the-hall-california-benefit-concert-review.html |title=All for the Hall California benefit concert review \xe2\x80\x93 NashvilleGab \xe2\x80\x93 Country music news and Nashville celebrity gossip |publisher=NashvilleGab |date=October 6, 2009 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

In 2010, Harris regrouped with the latest version of the Red Dirt Boys\xe2\x80\x94Madeira, Owings, Donohue, and Simpkins\xe2\x80\x94for Lilith Fair summer dates and a scheduled US autumn tour.

According to an interview with [[Bonnie Tyler]] by Digital Spy, Emmylou Harris will be teaming up with her on Tyler\'s upcoming album. Harris will do backing vocals on a song, written and produced by Wayne Warner. A recent solo album, \'\'[[Hard Bargain (Emmylou Harris)|Hard Bargain]]\'\', was released on the [[Nonesuch Records|Nonesuch]] label on April 26, 2011.  It reached #3 on \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\'\'s Country Albums chart \xe2\x80\x93 Emmy\'s highest charting album since 1980 \xe2\x80\x93 and the Top 20 of the Pop Albums chart.

[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] host [[Tavis Smiley]] interviewed Harris in a program that aired on April 20, 2011. In the interview Harris spoke of being a straight-A student in high school, which led her to being selected as valedictorian, and recounted learning to play guitar by memorizing three chords.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://video.pbs.org/video/1891916330 |title=Video: Musician Emmylou Harris &#124; Watch Tavis Smiley Online &#124; PBS Video |publisher=Video.pbs.org |date=April 20, 2011 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

Later in 2011, she collaborated with Australian musician and screenwriter [[Nick Cave]] on the soundtrack to [[John Hillcoat]]\'s film \'\'[[Lawless (film)|Lawless]]\'\'. Set in Depression-era Franklin County, Virginia, US, the film was released in August 2012 (US) and September 2012 (UK).

The 2012 single "Emmylou" by Swedish folk duo [[First Aid Kit (band)|First Aid Kit]] on their album \'\'[[The Lion\'s Roar (album)|The Lion\'s Roar]]\'\' is, in part, a tribute to Harris, with its lyrics referring to her relationship to Gram Parsons.

In September 2012, she will be featured in a campaign called "30 Songs/30 Days" to support \'\'[[Half the Sky: Turning Oppression into Opportunity for Women Worldwide]]\'\', a multi-platform media project inspired by Nicholas Kristof and Sheryl WuDunn\'s book.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.halftheskymovement.org/blog/entry/30-songs-30-days-for-half-the-sky1 |title=30 Songs / 30 Days for Half the Sky &#124; Half The Sky |publisher=Halftheskymovement.org |date=August 30, 2012 |accessdate=2012-09-17}}</ref>

\'\'[[Old Yellow Moon]]\'\', an album of duets featuring Harris and former Hot Band member [[Rodney Crowell]], was released on February 26, 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/emmylou-harris-rodney-crowell-duet-on-hanging-up-my-heart-song-premiere-20121204 |title=Emmylou Harris, Rodney Crowell Duet on \'Hanging Up My Heart\' Song Premiere &#124; Music News |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=December 4, 2012 |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> It was another Billboard Top 10 Country album for Harris and obtained her 13th [[Grammy Award]] (2014).

== Activism ==
In 1997 and 1998, Harris performed in [[Sarah McLachlan]]\'s [[Lilith Fair]], promoting [[feminism]] in music. Since 1999, Harris has been organizing an annual benefit tour called Concerts for a Landmine Free World. All proceeds from the tours support the [[Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation]]\'s (VVAF) efforts to assist innocent victims of conflicts around the world. The tour also benefits the VVAF\'s work to raise [[United States|America]]\'s awareness of the global [[land mine|landmine]] problem. Artists that have joined Harris on the road for these dates include [[Mary Chapin Carpenter]], [[Bruce Cockburn]], [[Sheryl Crow]], [[Steve Earle]], [[Joan Baez]], [[Patty Griffin]], [[Nanci Griffith]], [[Willie Nelson]], and [[Lucinda Williams]]. Harris is a supporter of [[animal rights]] and an active member of [[People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals|PETA]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kentuckyfriedcruelty.com/EmmyLouHarris.asp |title=Celebrity Support :: Emmylou Harris |publisher=Kentucky Fried Cruelty |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref> She founded, and in her spare time assists at, Bonapart\'s Retreat, an [[animal shelter]] in Nashville.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.emmylou.net/br.html |title=Bonaparte\'s Retreat |publisher=Emmylou.net |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref>

She became a member of the newly formed Commission on the Humanities and Social Sciences of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bestcountrysingers.com/emmylou-harris/item-news/pre-da20110217-C149B81D3F.html |title=Emmylou Harris news: |publisher=Bestcountrysingers.com |date= |accessdate=2014-07-15}}</ref><ref>[http://www.humanitiescommission.org/aboutCommission/memberList.aspx ]{{dead link|date=July 2014}}</ref>

\'\'\'Bob Woodruff\'\'\' (born March 14, 1961 in [[New York City]]<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p139598|pure_url=yes}} |title=Bob Woodruff biography |accessdate=2008-05-04 |last=Leaver |first=Jack |work=[[Allmusic]]}}</ref>) is a critically acclaimed American [[country music]] singer and songwriter. Initially, he was a member of a country rock band called The Fields before beginning a career as a solo artist. He released four studio albums (1994\'s \'\'Dreams & Saturday Nights\'\', 1997\'s \'\'Desire Road\'\', 2011\'s \'\'The Lost Kerosene Tapes, 1999\'\' and 2013\'s \'\'The Year We Tried to Kill the Pain\'\' <ref name="allmusic"/>) and has charted two singles on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' country music charts, as well as a third on the \'\'[[RPM (magazine)|RPM]]\'\' Country Tracks chart in Canada. Woodruff\'s second album included [[cover version|cover]]s of songs by [[John Fogerty]] and [[Arthur Alexander]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mansfield|first=Brian|date=June 1997|title=Bob Woodruff|journal=New Country|volume=4|issue=6|pages=40|issn=1086-1076}}</ref> His latest album, \'\'The Year We Tried To Kill The Pain\'\', was released in Europe in September 2013 and debuted at #1 on the EuroAmericana Chart in November 2013.

 ****** The Whybirds

b'{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians -->
| name                = The Whybirds
| image               =
| caption             =
| image_size          =
| background          = group_or_band
| alias               =
| origin              = [[Bedford]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]]
| genre               = [[alt.country]]/[[rock music]]
| years_active        = 2006\xe2\x80\x93present
| label               = The Little Red Recording Company
| associated_acts     =
| website             = [http://www.thewhybirds.com/ www.thewhybirds.com]
| current_members     = Dave Banks<br />Ben Haswell<br />Luke Tuchscherer
| past_members        = Taff Thatcher
}}
The Whybirds are a three-piece [[rock music|rock]]/[[alt.country]] band from [[Bedford]], [[England]]. They have released three full-length studio albums to date as well as a live album and an EP.<ref>http://www.thewhybirds.com/store.html</ref>

== Biography ==

The Whybirds formed in 2006, composed of Dave Banks (vocals, guitar), Ben Haswell (vocals, guitar), Taff Thatcher (vocals, bass) and Luke Tuchscherer (vocals, drums). From its inception, the group has been notable for the fact that all members share lead vocal and songwriting duties, in a manner that has been compared to [[The Band]].<ref name="songwritingmagazine1">{{cite web|url=http://www.songwritingmagazine.co.uk/features/interview-the-whybirds/14011 |title=Interview: The Whybirds |publisher=Songwriting Magazine |date=2013-11-26 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref name="Wilding, Phil 2010">Wilding, Phil. "High Hopes", \'\'[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]\'\', August 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americana-uk.com/archives/interview-archives/interviews-pre-2010/interviews-2007/itemlist/tag/The%20Whybirds |title=Displaying items by tag: The Whybirds |publisher=americanaUK |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

The group met at school, where Haswell, Tuchscherer and Thatcher had originally played together in The View. The View disbanded in 2005 and the three joined with Banks to form The Whybirds a year later.<ref name="Freeman, Richie">{{cite web|author=Freeman, Richie |url=http://penseyeview.wordpress.com/2008/02/24/todays-feature-february-23-24-the-whybirds/ |title=Today\xe2\x80\x99s Feature \xe2\x80\x93 February 23-24: The Whybirds &#124; PensEyeView.com |publisher=Penseyeview.wordpress.com |date=2008-02-24 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> However, Taff Thatcher left The Whybirds in 2012 and Haswell moved from guitar to bass.<ref>{{cite web|author=Friday |url=http://www.prescriptionmusicpruk.com/press-releases/2013/9/6/the-whybirds-a-little-blood-is-out-on-november-4.html |title=The Whybirds\' \'A Little Blood\' is out on November 4 - Press releases - Music PR UK, Music Promotion and Band Promotion |publisher=Prescriptionmusicpruk.com |date=2013-09-06 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

The band members cite their influences as [[Bruce Springsteen]], [[Steve Earle]], [[Neil Young]], [[The Replacements (band)|The Replacements]], [[Uncle Tupelo]], [[Ryan Adams]], [[Pearl Jam]] and [[My Morning Jacket]].<ref>http://www.songwritingmagazine.co.uk/features/interview-the-whybirds/14011</ref>

As for the band\'s name, Tuchscherer said in 2010: \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a reference to [[The Byrds]]. Their \'\'[[Sweetheart of the Rodeo]]\'\' is the definitive [[country rock]] album, and they obviously spelt their name with a \xe2\x80\x98Y\xe2\x80\x99. So essentially it\xe2\x80\x99s a nod to them.<ref name="Wilding, Phil 2010"/>\xe2\x80\x9d However, in a 2008 interview the band said it was also a nod to [[The Yardbirds]].<ref name="Freeman, Richie"/>

As well as The Band, The Whybirds have been compared to Bruce Springsteen, [[The Who]],<ref name="rollingstone1">{{cite web|url=http://rollingstone.es/noticias/view/diez-buenas-bandas-de-rock-que-quiza-no-conozcas |title=Diez buenas bandas de rock que quiz\xc3\xa1 no conozcas en RollingStone |publisher=Rollingstone.es |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[Tom Petty]],<ref name="maverick-country1">{{cite web|url=http://www.maverick-country.com/cdreviewsmain.asp?pl=753 |title=Maverick - The UK\'s Leading Independent Country Music Magazine |publisher=Maverick-country.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Pearl Jam, [[The Allman Brothers]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americana-uk.com/interview-archive/interviews-2008/item/542-the-whybirds |title=The Whybirds |publisher=americanaUK |date=2008-09-16 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Neil Young (specifically with [[Crazy Horse]]),<ref name="movingtone1">{{cite web|url=http://www.movingtone.com/reviews/cd-review-rychard-carrington-reviews-cold-blue-sky-whybirds |title=CD Review: Rychard Carrington reviews Cold Blue Sky - The Whybirds |publisher=Moving Tone |date=2010-05-13 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[Alex Chilton]] and [[Warren Zevon]]<ref name="rockshot1">{{cite web|author=Video: The Whybirds. The Crows Caw. - Rockshot says: |url=http://rockshot.co.uk/dir/8795/reviewl-whybirds-little-blood/ |title=Review: The Whybirds. A Little Blood - Rock Shot UKRock Shot UK |publisher=Rockshot.co.uk |date=2013-10-22 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> among others.

== Recording career ==

=== \'\'Tonight EP\'\' & \'\'The Whybirds\'\' (2007-2008) ===

The band\'s first release was the \'\'Tonight EP\'\' in August 2007, followed by their self-titled debut album in March 2008. Both were produced by Nick Mailing \xe2\x80\x93 who produced [[The Quireboys]]\' \'\'[[Well Oiled (The Quireboys album)|Well Oiled]]\'\' and \'\'[[Homewreckers & Heartbreakers]]\'\' records \xe2\x80\x93 at the same sessions in March/April 2007 at Lost Boys Studio in [[Cranfield]], Bedfordshire. \'\'The Whybirds\'\' album was launched at [[The Barfly]] in [[Camden Town]] in March 2008 but received little press attention on release.<ref>http://www.thewhybirds.com</ref>

=== \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\', \'\'Live Recordings Vol. 1\'\' and national press attention (2009-2011) ===

The Whybirds\' sophomore album, \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\', was recorded with the help of [[Elliot Mazer]],<ref name="songwritingmagazine1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uaudio.com/blog/elliot-mazer-ua-interview/ |title=Elliot Mazer: A Master Producer Combines the Best of Analog and Digital \xe2\x80\x94 Including the New UAD-2 SOLO/Laptop - Blog - Universal Audio |publisher=Uaudio.com |date=2009-06-24 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> who produced [[Neil Young]]\'s \'\'[[Harvest]]\'\' and worked on recordings by The Byrds, The Band, [[Janis Joplin]] and [[Linda Ronstadt]] among others. Mazer worked on early sessions, but was unable to make it back from [[New York City]] when the album was being finished.<ref name="Wilding, Phil 2010"/>

\'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\' was ultimately co-produced by the band and Tom Peters \xe2\x80\x93 whose credits include [[Matt Cardle]], [[Cradle of Filth]], [[Porcupine Tree]] and [[Bonzo Dog Doo-Dah Band]]<ref>{{cite web|author=info@blue-compass.com |url=http://www.musicnetworkpro.com/uk/view.php?uid=325233 |title=Tom Peters, Producer |location=52.24223;0.70733 |publisher=Musicnetworkpro.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> \xe2\x80\x93 at Monkey Puzzle House in [[Woolpit]], [[Suffolk]] in the summer of 2009.<ref>http://monkeypuzzlehouse.com/clients.php</ref>

The record was launched at a show at [[The Garage, London]] in [[Islington]] in November 2009,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IrUcfBfllaQ |title=The Whybirds 2009 @ Garage Rosalita |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-11-08 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> ahead of its official release in March 2010.

\'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\' was met with critical acclaim from the UK and European music press upon its release in 2010, with positive reviews from publications such as \'\'[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]\'\' (7/10),<ref>Fielder, Hugh. "Pure Prairie League", \'\'[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]\'\', August 2010.</ref> \'\'Maverick Country\'\' (4/5)<ref>CB, Maverick Country Magazine, June 2010</ref> and \'\'[[R2 (Rock\'n\'Reel)]]\'\' (4/5),<ref>Carrington, Rychard. [[R2 (Rock\'n\'Reel)]], May/June 2010</ref><ref>http://www.movingtone.com/reviews/cd-review-rychard-carrington-reviews-cold-blue-sky-whybirds</ref> as well as other music websites such as Eurorock,<ref>{{cite web|last=Perkins |first=Jeff |url=http://blogcritics.org/music-review-the-whybirds-cold-blue/ |title=Music Review: The Whybirds \xe2\x80\x93 Cold Blue Sky |publisher=Blogcritics |date=2010-05-30 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Northern Sky,<ref>{{cite web|author=Allan Wilkinson |url=http://www.allanwilkinson.co.uk/node/895 |title=Album Review: The Whybirds - Cold Blue Sky (Little Red Recording) &#124; Northern Sky |publisher=Allanwilkinson.co.uk |date=2010-05-30 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Power Metal (9/10)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://powermetal.de/review/review-Whybirds__The/Cold_Blue_Sky,16263.html |title=Review &#124; WHYBIRDS, THE - Cold Blue Sky |publisher=Powermetal.De |date=2010-06-22 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> and Americana UK (7/10).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.workingtitle.co/drafts/auk/modules.php?op=modload&name=Reviews&file=index&req=showcontent&id=5297 |title=Americana UK :: The UK Home for Alt-Country, Americana and Alternative |publisher=Workingtitle.co |date=2010-03-05 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

Eduardo Izquierdo, writing in Spanish magazine \'\'Ruta 66\'\', said: \xe2\x80\x9cBeautiful melodies, rich instrumentation... Honesty, feeling, variety, essence... Nothing is superfluous and nothing is lacking. One of my albums of the year.\xe2\x80\x9d<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reverbnation.com/thewhybirds/press/ |title=Press Item |publisher=Reverbnation.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

During 2010/11, The Whybirds toured [[Spain]] with the [[Drive-By Truckers]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.efeeme.com/en-noviembre-gira-de-drive-by-truckers-y-the-whybirds/ |title=En noviembre, gira de Drive-By Truckers y The Whybirds |publisher=Efe Eme |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> played festivals including [[Azkena Rock Festival]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.azkenarockfestival.com/arf/2013/index.php/the-whybirds.html?lang=es-ES |title=The Whybirds |publisher=Azkenarockfestival.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[Secret Garden Party]],<ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/secretgarden/2011</ref> [[Summer Sundae]], [[Rhythms of the World]], Off the Tracks and the [[Rhythm Festival]] <ref>{{cite web|author=Virtual Festivals: http://www.virtualfestivals.com |url=http://www.virtualfestivals.com/The-Whybirds |title=The Whybirds at Festivals |publisher=Virtualfestivals.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> and supported artists such as [[Evan Dando]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thedjlist.com/events/bedford-gb/esquiresbedford_evan_dando_lemonheads_liam_dullaghan/ |title=Evan Dando (Lemonheads) + Liam Dullaghan + The Whybirds ***SOLD OUT***, Bedford, GB |publisher=The DJ List |date=2011-07-05 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[The Quireboys]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.list.co.uk/event/20024078-the-quireboys-the-whybirds/ |title=The Quireboys, The Whybirds |publisher=The List |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[The Union (band)|The Union]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicrockmagazine.com/news/the-union-tour-supports-named/ |title=The Union: Tour Supports Named &#124; News &#124; Classic Rock |publisher=Classicrockmagazine.com |date=2010-09-23 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> [[Jason & The Scorchers]]<ref>{{cite web|author=This is Leicestershire |url=http://www.thisisleicestershire.co.uk/event/Jason-Scorchers-Whybirds/event-16836367-detail/event.html#axzz2g6MxtDjS |title=Jason And The Scorchers, The Whybirds &#124; Leicester Mercury |publisher=Thisisleicestershire.co.uk |date=2012-09-06 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> and [[Alejandro Escovedo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jcplmusic.com/the-whybirds-to-open-for-alejandro-escovedo/ |title=The Whybirds To Open For Alejandro Escovedo |publisher=Jcplmusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

In the \'\'Classic Rock\'\' Awards 2010, the magazine named "Jenny, Can We Take a Ride?" as their 33rd best song of the year, calling the track a "slice of blinding blue-collar country rock from the Bruce Springsteens of Bedford".<ref>"Critics\' Choice Songs of 2010", \'\'[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]\'\', January 2011.</ref>

In 2011, [[Rolling Stone]] called them one of the top 10 bands to watch.<ref name="rollingstone1"/>

The band\'s full length [[live album]], \'\'Live Recordings Vol.1\'\' \xe2\x80\x93 mixed by former Quireboy Chris Corney \xe2\x80\x93 was released in 2011 to good reviews.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movingtone.com/reviews/cd-review-rychard-carrington-reviews-live-recordings-vol-1-whybirds |title=CD Review: Rychard Carrington reviews Live Recordings Vol. 1 - The Whybirds |publisher=Moving Tone |date=2011-10-29 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://djhimaging.com/?p=471 |title=The Whybirds \xe2\x80\x93 Live CD &#124; |publisher=Djhimaging.com |date=2011-01-02 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

The record features numerous [[segue]]s and extended periods of [[improvisation]] \xe2\x80\x93 in a style reminiscent of a [[jam band]] \xe2\x80\x93 which have long been part of the band\'s shows. Indeed, like many other jam bands, The Whybirds have an open taping policy, and many of their concerts have been uploaded to the [[Live Music Archive]] for free download.<ref>http://archive.org/details/TheWhybirds</ref>

=== New lineup (2012) ===

Thatcher left the group in February 2012, citing "how fickle the music industry is" and him becoming "extremely disillusioned with the whole concept of trying to sell music" as contributing factors. True to that sentiment, Thatcher releases music completely free of charge under the name The Quaint & The Curious.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thequaintandthecurious.net/interviews/ |title=Interviews &#124; The Quaint & the Curious |publisher=Thequaintandthecurious.net |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

Following the split, The Whybirds took some time to "relearn how to be a band" and during this period, the group nearly disbanded entirely. Singer/drummer Luke Tuchscherer was quoted by Songwriting Magazine as saying: \xe2\x80\x9cWhen Taff left, the initial discussion was around getting another bassist. But we didn\xe2\x80\x99t even get to the point of auditioning anyone, because we just thought they\xe2\x80\x99d have to be a brilliant bass player and a brilliant singer, plus Taff was a great songwriter. That\xe2\x80\x99s already pretty big shoes for anyone to fill. On top of that, the rest of us have been playing together for years and are best friends, so no-one would\xe2\x80\x99ve wanted to come into the band. So there appeared to be no other option other than to quit, but then Ben said, \xe2\x80\x98Why don\xe2\x80\x99t I play bass?\xe2\x80\x99 That saved the band really.\xe2\x80\x9d<ref name="songwritingmagazine1"/>

=== \'\'A Little Blood\'\' (2013) ===

Work on the follow up to \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\' began in early 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.movingtone.com/news/whybirds-recording-third-album |title=NEWS: Whybirds recording third album |publisher=Moving Tone |date=2012-11-30 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> and the single "The Cure" was released on 2 September 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seenitheardit.com/2013/08/whybirds-stream-single-the-cure/ |title=The Whybirds stream new single: \'The Cure\' |publisher=Seenitheardit.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiralearth.co.uk/news/story.asp?nid=7909 |title=The Whybirds: new album & single stream |publisher=SpiralEarth |date=2013-08-21 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=RAMzineRAMzine |url=http://ramzine.co.uk/news/the-whybirds-stream-new-single-the-cure/ |title=The Whybirds stream new single, \xe2\x80\x98The Cure\xe2\x80\x99 |publisher=RAMzine |date=2013-08-13 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

The single "The Crow\'s Caw" was released on 21 October with an accompanying video before third studio album \'\'A Little Blood\'\' was officially released on 4 November 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.classicrockmagazine.com/music_and_videos/the-whybirds-premiere-the-crows-caw/ |title=The Whybirds premiere: The Crow\'s Caw &#124; Video &#124; Classic Rock |publisher=Classicrockmagazine.com |date=2013-10-30 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> The record was partly [[crowdfunded]] via [[Pledge Music]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pledgemusic.com/projects/thewhybirds |title=The Whybirds: The third studio album on PledgeMusic |publisher=Pledgemusic.com |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

\'\'A Little Blood\'\' was produced by Nick Mailing<ref name="songwritingmagazine1"/> at Lost Boys Studio, Cranfield and Alexander Sound Studio in [[Milton Keynes]] and mixed by Tom Peters. The record saw The Whybirds going in a "meaner, darker, grittier" direction due to both the change in lineup and the mood within the band.<ref name="indielondon1">{{cite web|url=http://www.indielondon.co.uk/Music-Review/the-whybirds-a-little-blood-review |title=The Whybirds - A Little Blood (Review) - Your London Reviews |publisher=IndieLondon |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

In a press release accompanying the album,<ref>{{cite web|author=Friday |url=http://www.prescriptionmusicpruk.com/press-releases/2013/9/6/the-whybirds-a-little-blood-is-out-on-november-4.html#.Us01iejcZ7k |title=The Whybirds\' \'A Little Blood\' is out on November 4 - Press releases - Music PR UK, Music Promotion and Band Promotion |publisher=Prescriptionmusicpruk.com |date=2013-09-06 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Dave Banks was quoted as saying: \xe2\x80\x9cEverything good we thought would happen to us leading up to and after \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\' just didn\xe2\x80\x99t. The new record is about three guys crashing into their thirties, and realising it isn\xe2\x80\x99t what they thought it would be. A lot of the characters in these songs don\xe2\x80\x99t necessarily have a lot going for them. But for some of them, there is still a little hope.\xe2\x80\x9d

Tuchscherer was quoted by Spiral Earth as saying: "The last one, \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\', had a very optimistic feel to it. We as a band were being promised the earth, we were younger, less jaded\xe2\x80\xa6 This record, well, I think the things that happened to us between this one and the last \xe2\x80\x93 including losing a member \xe2\x80\x93 influenced the songs greatly. The record, to me, is about hitting your 30s, with the backdrop of maybe not having the best government, people struggling to get by, having dreams go unfilled\xe2\x80\xa6but still being alive. The song \xe2\x80\x9cA Little Blood\xe2\x80\x9d is talking about one thing, but for me, the album\xe2\x80\x99s title is summed up by the penultimate track, where it says: \'They ain\xe2\x80\x99t killed us yet, there\xe2\x80\x99s a little blood to bleed\'."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiralearth.co.uk/news/kusharstory.asp?nid=8041 |title=Dave Kushar - Interviews and features from folk to blues |publisher=Spiralearth.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

The album received positive reviews in the UK national press from publications including \'\'[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]\'\' (7/10),<ref>Staunton, Terry "Lively and varied guitar rock grooves", \'\'[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]\'\', November 2010</ref> \'\'Powerplay\'\' (7/10),<ref>Powerplay Magazine, November 2013</ref> \'\'[[Scottish Daily Express]]\'\' (4/5),<ref>"Weekend Music Album Reviews", \'\'[[Scottish Daily Express]]\'\', 26 October 2013</ref> \'\'[[R2 (Rock\'n\'Reel)]]\'\' (4/5),<ref>Carter, Chris, "Rock Reviews", \'\'[[R2 (Rock\'n\'Reel)]]\'\', November/December 2013. Vol2 No42</ref> as well as websites such as Songwriting Magazine (5/5),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.songwritingmagazine.co.uk/music-reviews/a-little-blood-by-the-whybirds-album/13803 |title=A Little Blood by The Whybirds (Album) |publisher=Songwriting Magazine |date=2013-11-13 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Americana UK (7/10),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americana-uk.com/cd-reviews/item/the-whybirds-a-little-blood-the-little-red-recording-company-2015 |title=The Whybirds; " A Little Blood" (The Little Red Recording Company 2013) |publisher=americanaUK |date=2014-01-06 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> Renacer El\xc3\xa9ctrico Music Magazine,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.renacerelectricomusicmag.com/2014/01/the-whybirds-little-blood-little-red.html |title=Renacer El\xc3\xa9ctrico - Reviews |publisher=http://www.renacerelectricomusicmag.com |date= |accessdate=2014-02-05}}</ref> Fatea <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fatea-records.co.uk/magazine/2013/Whybirds.html |title=FATEA - Reviews |publisher=Fatea-records.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> and Indie London (3.5/5).<ref name="indielondon1"/> It received an average review from \'\'Maverick Country\'\' (3/5).<ref name="maverick-country1"/>

In a positive review in the February 2014 issue of \'\'Classic Rock\'\', critic Philip Wilding said: "Critical acclaim can only carry a band so far. A case in point is the feverish plaudits that greeted The Whybirds\' 2010 album \'\'Cold Blue Sky\'\', with the band lauded as England\'s answer to the Allmans... This album is an exercise in realisation. Grittier, darker tones, downbeat lyrics. The writing\xe2\x80\x99s on the wall. The band\xe2\x80\x99s songwriting still shines through the fuzz, though \xe2\x80\x93 songs like \'Never Let You Go\' and \'More Than He Could Stand\' are brittle but beautiful. Their heads might be hung low, but their songs still resonate."<ref>Wilding, Philip, "Darker, meaner, stripped back", \'\'[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]]\'\', February 2014</ref>

\'\'Classic Rock Society\'\' magazine wrote in its Jan/Feb 2014 issue that the record "...funnels Jayhawks Americana through the English [[power trio]] sound and gives us some hard, anthemic, big chorus, sing-along rock tracks. Driving rock that needs to be played loud. Remember the name, these guys are going to be huge."<ref>JRT, "Synopsis", \'\'Classic Rock Society\'\', p51, Issue 199, Jan/Feb 2014</ref>

The record placed at number seven in Americana UK\'s album chart.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americana-uk.com/ |title=The UK Home of Americana |publisher=americanaUK |date= |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

Songwriting Magazine named "The Cure" as a runner up in its Best Rock Songs of 2013 list and the band as a whole as one of the most overlooked bands of the year, saying "we can\'t see why their records aren\'t flying off digital shelves".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.songwritingmagazine.co.uk/features/best-of-2013/14610 |title=Best Of 2013 |publisher=Songwriting Magazine |date=2013-12-31 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

=== Spanish Tour, Tuchscherer solo album (2014-present) ===

In late 2013 it was announced that the band would be embarking on an eight-date tour of Spain in February 2014,<ref>{{cite web|last=Rodriguez |first=Alfredo |url=http://www.musicazul.com/noticias-the-whybirds-estaran-actuando-en-directo-en-nuestro-pais-durante-el-proximo-mes-de-febrero/ |title=The Whybirds estar\xc3\xa1n actuando en directo en nuestro pa\xc3\xads durante el pr\xc3\xb3ximo mes de febrero |publisher=Musicazul |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref> which was well received by critics.<ref name="lachatarreria.com">http://www.lachatarreria.com/2014/03/03/the-whybirds-19-02-2014-boite-live-madrid/</ref><ref name="lachatarreria.com"/><ref>http://www.todomusicarock.org/cronica-de-the-whybirds-200114-sala-boite/?utm_source=twitterfeed&utm_medium=twitter</ref><ref>http://www.nurocks.com/2014/02/whybirds-22-de-febrero-barcelona-sala.html</ref><ref>http://www.ruta66.es/2014/02/vivos/the-whybirds-sala-rocksound-barcelona/</ref><ref>http://gravelroad76.wordpress.com/2014/02/17/the-whybirds-spanish-tour-2014/</ref><ref>http://blog.rocklive.es/2014/02/cronica-concierto-santiago-delgado.html</ref>

In March 2014, Tuchscherer announced a [[Pledge Music]] campaign for his debut solo record. The album, \'\'You Get So Alone At Times That It Just Makes Sense\'\', is named after a book by [[Charles Bukowski]]. Produced by Tom Peters, the record features Banks and Haswell from the band, as well as other guests including Max Hart ([[We Are Scientists]], [[Katy Perry]]), Nick Mailing (The Quireboys), Chris Corney (The Quireboys) and Simon Rinaldo (Pearl Handled Revolver), with string arrangements by Bedford composer Johnny Parry.<ref>http://www.beat-surrender.com/2014/03/06/luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at-times-that-it-just-makes-sense-pledge-campaign/</ref><ref>http://www.pledgemusic.com/projects/yougetsoalone</ref> The Pledge campaign hit 120% halfway through the 60-day period and it was later announced that the album\'s official release would be 6 October 2014.

When asked \xe2\x80\x93 in an interview with Spanish magazine \'\'Ruta 66\'\' \xe2\x80\x93 why he needed to make a solo album, Tuchscherer said: "I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I \'\'needed\'\' to, but basically, Tom Peters asked me at the end of 2010 whether I\xe2\x80\x99d like to do some recording with him. I asked the others if they had a problem, no one said they did, so in January 2011 I went into the studio with Tom." He said that the album was recorded in a week or so, with the days spread out over two years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ruta66.es/2014/07/encuentros/luke-tuchscherer-suenos-que-se-hacen-realidad/ |title=Luke Tuchscherer, sue\xc3\xb1os que se hacen realidad
 |publisher=Ruta 66 |date=2014-07-04 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>http://luketuchscherer.tumblr.com/post/90758038499/interview-with-ruta-66</ref>

To mark the release date, a video for the song "Hold On" was unveiled.<ref>http://www.rightchordmusic.co.uk/luke-tuchscherer-hold-on/</ref> Upon release, the album attracted universally positive reviews from a number of UK and European websites and magazines.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://slatethedisco.com/2014/06/album-review-luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at-times-it-makes-sense/ |title=album review // Luke Tuchscherer \xe2\x80\x98You Get So Alone At Times It Makes Sense\xe2\x80\x99|publisher=Slate The Disco |date=2014-06-22 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://phillycheezeblues.blogspot.co.uk/2014/06/luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at.html|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense |publisher=PhillyCheeze\xe2\x80\x99s Rock and Blues Reviews |date=2014-06-07 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://thealternateroot.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2365:lt-ygsaattijms&Itemid=301&Itemidindex_php?option=com_content&catid=223:new-releases-row-2|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense |publisher=The Alternate Root |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fatea-records.co.uk/magazine/2014/LukeTuchscherer.html|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense  |publisher=Fatea |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://threechordsandthetruthuk.blogspot.co.uk/2014/09/luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at.html?m=1|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense  |publisher=Three Chords & The Truth |date=2014-09-18 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanrootsuk.com/luke-tuchscherer---you-get-so-alone-at-times-that-it-just-makes-sense.html|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense  |publisher=American Roots UK |date=2014-08-22 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rightchordmusic.co.uk/artist-of-the-week-luke-tuchscherer/|title=Artist of the Week: Luke Tuchscherer  |publisher=Right Chord Music |date=2014-08-18 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://paulkerr.wordpress.com/2014/09/22/luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at-times-that-it-makes-sense/|title=Luke Tuchscherer - You Get So Alone at Times That it Just Makes Sense  |publisher=Blabber \'n\' Smoke |date=2014-09-22 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

In an 8/10 review, \'\'Americana UK\'\' said: "Tuchscherer\xe2\x80\x99s ability to create such an engaging collection of sad songs and waltzes should ensure that \'\'You Get So Alone At Times That It Just Makes Sense\'\' will be a contender for an appearance on any year end list."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americana-uk.com/cd-reviews/item/luke-tuchscherer-you-get-so-alone-at-times-that-it-just-makes-sense |title=Whybird man soars on solo flight |publisher=Americana UK |date=2014-07-10 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>

In a 4/5 review, \'\'[[R2 (Rock\'n\'Reel)]]\'\' said: \xe2\x80\x9cAn impressive collection of 12 well-crafted songs\xe2\x80\xa6 It\xe2\x80\x99s an excellent debut that reminds us of [[Ryan Adams]]\xe2\x80\x99 \'\'[[Heartbreaker (Ryan Adams album)|Heartbreaker]]\'\' in its thematic and emotional impact \xe2\x80\x93 a great compliment indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d<ref>http://luketuchscherer.tumblr.com/post/97728728999/four-star-review-from-rock-n-reel</ref>

Belgian website \'\'Ctrl.Alt.Country\'\' gave the album four stars out of five and called it "[[Americana music|Americana]] at its finest".<ref>http://www.ctrlaltcountry.be/Pagina1.htm#LukeTuchscherer</ref>

Tuchscherer said in an interview with \'\'Local Secrets\'\' that The Whybirds were "kicking songs around now for a new record. We\xe2\x80\x99ve got about eight and plenty more to work on. The new stuff is sounding really good."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.localsecrets.com/ezine.cfm?ezineid=4530~the-whybirds-country-rock+gigs-and-nightlife |title=The Whybirds: Country Rock |publisher=Local Secrets|date=2014-09-10 |accessdate=2014-01-15}}</ref>
