\'\'\'The Byrds\'\'\' {{IPAc-en|\xcb\x88|b|\xc9\x9cr|d|z}} were an American [[Rock music|rock]] band, formed in Los Angeles, California in 1964.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|authorlink=Richie Unterberger|title=Biography of The Byrds|publisher=[[AllMusic]]|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p3810|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref>  The band underwent multiple line-up changes throughout its existence, with frontman [[Roger McGuinn]] (known as Jim McGuinn until mid-1967) remaining the sole consistent member, until the group disbanded in 1973.<ref name="allmusic2">{{cite web|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|title=Biography of Roger McGuinn|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p104158|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref>  Although they only managed to attain the huge commercial success of contemporaries like [[the Beatles]], [[the Beach Boys]], and [[the Rolling Stones]] for a short period (1965\xe2\x80\x9366), the Byrds are today considered by critics to be one of the most influential bands of the 1960s.<ref name="allmusic"/>  Initially, they pioneered the musical genre of [[folk rock]], melding the influence of the Beatles and other [[British Invasion]] bands with contemporary and traditional [[folk music]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Folk-Rock Overview|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=explore|id=style/d417|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-03-15}}</ref>  As the 1960s progressed, the band was also influential in originating [[psychedelic rock]], [[raga rock]], and [[country rock]].<ref name="allmusic"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Psychedelic Rock Overview|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=explore|id=style/d380|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-01-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Bellman, Jonathan.|authorlink=Jonathan Bellman|page=351|year=1997|title=The Exotic In Western Music|publisher=Northeastern Publishing|isbn=1-55553-319-1}}</ref>

The band\'s signature blend of clear [[Vocal harmony|harmony singing]] and McGuinn\'s jangly [[Twelve-string guitar|twelve-string]] [[Rickenbacker]] [[Electric guitar|guitar]] has continued to be influential on popular music up to the present day.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="smith">{{cite book|author=Smith, Chris.|pages=32\xe2\x80\x9334|year=2009|title=101 Albums That Changed Popular Music|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0-19-537371-5}}</ref>  Among the band\'s most enduring songs are their [[cover version]]s of [[Bob Dylan]]\'s "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]" and [[Pete Seeger]]\'s "[[Turn! Turn! Turn!|Turn! Turn! Turn! (to Everything There Is a Season)]]", along with the self-penned originals, "[[I\'ll Feel a Whole Lot Better]]", "[[Eight Miles High]]", "[[So You Want to Be a Rock \'n\' Roll Star]]", "[[Ballad of Easy Rider]]" and "[[Chestnut Mare]]".

The original five-piece line-up of the Byrds consisted of [[Roger McGuinn|Jim McGuinn]] ([[lead guitar]], [[Singing|vocals]]), [[Gene Clark]] ([[tambourine]], vocals), [[David Crosby]] ([[rhythm guitar]], vocals), [[Chris Hillman]] ([[bass guitar]], vocals), and [[Michael Clarke (musician)|Michael Clarke]] ([[Drum kit|drums]]).<ref name="buckley">{{cite book|author=Buckley, Peter.|pages=155\xe2\x80\x93156|year=2003|title=The Rough Guide to Rock|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=1-84353-105-4}}</ref>  However, this version of the band was relatively short-lived and by early 1966, Clark had left due to problems associated with anxiety and his increasing isolation within the group.<ref name="einarson2">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=87\xe2\x80\x9389|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5|url = http://books.google.com/books?id=ZZUHknGVGx4C&printsec=frontcover}}</ref>  The Byrds continued as a quartet until late 1967, when Crosby and Clarke also departed the band.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|authorlink=Christopher Hjort|page=117|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965\xe2\x80\x931973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  McGuinn and Hillman decided to recruit new members, including country rock pioneer [[Gram Parsons]], but by late 1968, Hillman and Parsons had also exited the band.<ref name="allmusic"/>  McGuinn, who by this time had changed his name to Roger after a flirtation with the [[Subud]] religion,<ref name="allmusic2"/> elected to rebuild the band\'s membership and between 1968 and 1973, he helmed a new incarnation of the Byrds, featuring guitarist [[Clarence White]] among others.<ref name="allmusic"/>  McGuinn disbanded the then current line-up in early 1973, to make way for a reunion of the original quintet.<ref name="fricke8">{{cite AV media notes|title=Farther Along|titlelink=Farther Along (The Byrds album)|others=The Byrds|year=2000|chapter=Farther Along: The Byrds at Twilight|first=David|last=Fricke|authorlink=David Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]/[[Legacy Recordings|Legacy]]}}</ref>  The Byrds\' final album was released in March 1973, with the reunited group disbanding soon afterwards.<ref name="byrdwatcher10">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Byrds|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpbr.html|accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref>

Several former members of the band went on to successful careers of their own, either as solo artists or as members of such groups as [[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young]], [[the Flying Burrito Brothers]] and [[the Desert Rose Band]].<ref name="allmusic"/>  In the late 1980s, Gene Clark and Michael Clarke both began touring as the Byrds, prompting a legal challenge from McGuinn, Crosby, and Hillman over the rights to the band\'s name.<ref name="allmusic5">{{cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|title=Biography of Gene Clark|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p3910|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref>  As a result of this, McGuinn, Crosby, and Hillman performed a series of reunion [[Rock concert|concerts]] as the Byrds in 1989 and 1990, and also recorded four new Byrds\' songs.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|authorlink=Johnny Rogan|pages=425\xe2\x80\x93429|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=439\xe2\x80\x93440|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>

In January 1991, the Byrds were inducted into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]], an occasion that saw the five original members performing together for the last time.<ref name="einarson9">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=293\xe2\x80\x93294|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref><ref name="timeless34">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=445\xe2\x80\x93447|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  McGuinn, Crosby, and Hillman still remain active but Gene Clark died of a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]] in 1991, and Michael Clarke died of [[liver failure]] in 1993.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=510|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref><ref name="allmusic7">{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Biography of Michael Clarke|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p64877|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-25}}</ref>

==History==

===Formation (1964)===
{{quote box|width=23em|"McGuinn and I started picking together in The Troubadour bar which was called \'The Folk Den\' at the time ... We went into the lobby and started picking on the stairway where the echo was good and David came walking up and just started singing away with us doing the harmony part ... We hadn\'t even approached him."|\xe2\x80\x94Gene Clark recalling the encounter at The Troubadour folk club in Los Angeles that marked the genesis of the Byrds<ref name="timeless">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=33\xe2\x80\x9336|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>}}
The nucleus of the Byrds formed in early 1964, when [[Roger McGuinn|Jim McGuinn]], [[Gene Clark]], and [[David Crosby]] came together as a trio.<ref name="hjort">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=16\xe2\x80\x9317|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  All three musicians had a background rooted in folk music, with each one having worked as a folk singer on the acoustic [[coffeehouse]] circuit during the early 1960s.<ref name="allmusic"/>  In addition, they had all served time, independently of each other, as [[Sideman|sidemen]] in various "collegiate folk" groups: McGuinn with [[the Limeliters]] and the [[Chad Mitchell Trio]], Clark with [[the New Christy Minstrels]], and Crosby with [[Les Baxter|Les Baxter\'s Balladeers]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Russel|first=Richard E|title=Roger McGuinn: Founder of The Byrds|publisher=Roger McGuinn Home Page|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/jimmy/mcguinn/McGuinn.html|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Musicians Associated with the Byrds: The New Christy Minstrels|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/relassociates12.html#new|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref><ref name="allmusic13">{{cite web|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|title=Biography of David Crosby|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=david-crosby-p67471/biography|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref>  McGuinn had also spent time as a professional songwriter at the [[Brill Building]] in New York City, under the tutelage of [[Bobby Darin]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=11|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  By early 1964, McGuinn had become enamored with the music of [[the Beatles]], and had begun to intersperse his solo folk repertoire with acoustic versions of Beatles\' songs.<ref name="hjort"/>  While performing at [[The Troubadour (Los Angeles)|The Troubadour]] folk club in Los Angeles, McGuinn was approached by fellow Beatles fan Gene Clark, and the pair soon formed a [[Peter and Gordon]]-style duo, playing Beatles\' [[Cover version|covers]], [[Beatlesque]] renditions of traditional folk songs, and some self-penned material.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref name="hjort"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=31|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Soon after, David Crosby introduced himself to the duo at The Troubadour and began harmonizing with them on some of their songs.<ref name="timeless"/>  Impressed by the blend of their voices, the three musicians formed a trio and named themselves the Jet Set, a moniker inspired by McGuinn\'s love of aeronautics.<ref name="timeless"/>

Crosby introduced McGuinn and Clark to his associate Jim Dickson, who had access to [[Pacific Jazz Records|World Pacific Studios]], where he had been recording [[Demo (music)|demos]] of Crosby.<ref name="timeless"/>  Sensing the trio\'s potential, Dickson quickly took on [[Talent manager|management]] duties for the group, while his business partner, Eddie Tickner, became the group\'s accountant and financial manager.<ref name="timeless"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|author2=Hillman, Chris. |page=42|year=2008|title=Hot Burritos: The True Story of the Flying Burrito Brothers|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-16-9}}</ref>  Dickson began utilizing World Pacific Studios to record the trio as they honed their craft and perfected their blend of Beatles [[Pop music|pop]] and [[Bob Dylan]]-style folk.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=The Preflyte Sessions|titlelink=The Preflyte Sessions|others=The Byrds|year=2001|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=[[Sundazed Records]]}}</ref><ref name="byrdwatcher">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=In The Beginning|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpitb.html|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>  It was during the rehearsals at World Pacific that the band\'s folk rock sound\xe2\x80\x94an amalgam of their own Beatles-influenced material, their folk music roots and their Beatlesque covers of contemporary folk songs\xe2\x80\x94began to coalesce.<ref name="byrdwatcher"/>  Initially, this blend arose organically, but as rehearsals continued, the band began to actively attempt to bridge the gap between folk music and rock.<ref name="timeless"/><ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=The Byrds|titlelink=The Byrds (box set)|others=The Byrds|year=1990|first=David|last=Fricke|type=booklet|publisher=[[Columbia Records]]}}</ref>  Demo recordings made by the Jet Set at World Pacific Studios would later be collected on the [[compilation album]]s \'\'[[Preflyte]]\'\', \'\'[[In the Beginning (The Byrds album)|In the Beginning]]\'\', \'\'The Preflyte Sessions\'\' and \'\'Preflyte Plus\'\'.

[[Drummer]] [[Michael Clarke (musician)|Michael Clarke]] was added to the Jet Set in mid-1964.<ref name="hjort2">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=19\xe2\x80\x9320|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Clarke was recruited largely due to his good looks and [[Brian Jones|Brian Jones-esque]] hairstyle, rather than for his musical experience, which was limited to having played [[conga]]s in a semi-professional capacity in and around San Francisco and L.A.<ref name="timeless2">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=38\xe2\x80\x9340|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Clarke did not even own his own [[drum kit]] and initially had to play on a makeshift setup consisting of cardboard boxes and a [[tambourine]].<ref name="timeless2"/>  As the band continued to rehearse, Dickson arranged a one-off [[Single (music)|single]] deal for the group with [[Elektra Records]]\' founder [[Jac Holzman]].<ref name="einarson2"/>  The single, which coupled the band originals "Please Let Me Love You" and "[[It Won\'t Be Wrong|Don\'t Be Long]]", featured McGuinn, Clark, and Crosby, augmented by [[session musician]]s Ray Pohlman on [[bass guitar|bass]] and [[Earl Palmer]] on [[Drum kit|drums]].<ref name="einarson2"/>  In an attempt to cash in on the [[British Invasion]] craze that was dominating the American charts at the time, the band\'s name was changed for the single release to the suitably British-sounding the Beefeaters.<ref name="einarson2"/>  "Please Let Me Love You" was issued by Elektra Records on October 7, 1964, but it failed to chart.<ref name="timeless3">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=541\xe2\x80\x93548|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>

[[File:Rickenbacker 360-12 by Hal Hawkins - cropped.jpg|290px|thumb|left|A [[Rickenbacker 360/12|Rickenbacker 360 12-string guitar]] similar to the one used by Jim McGuinn in 1964 and 1965. By 1966, McGuinn had transitioned to playing the three [[Pickup (music technology)|pickup]] 370/12 model.]]
In August 1964, Dickson managed to acquire an [[acetate disc]] of the then-unreleased Bob Dylan song "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]", which he felt would make an effective cover for the Jet Set.<ref name="hjort2"/><ref name="timeless4">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=52\xe2\x80\x9355|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Although the band were initially unimpressed with the song, they began rehearsing it with a rock band [[arrangement]], changing the [[time signature]] from 2/4 to a rockier 4/4 configuration in the process.<ref name="timeless4"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Creswell, Toby.|authorlink=Toby Creswell|page=59|year=2006|title=1001 Songs: The Great Songs of All Time and the Artists, Stories and Secrets Behind Them|publisher=Da Capo Press|isbn=1-56025-915-9}}</ref>  In an attempt to bolster the group\'s confidence in the song, Dickson invited Dylan himself to  World Pacific to hear the band perform "Mr. Tambourine Man".<ref name="timeless4"/>  Impressed by the group\'s rendition, Dylan enthusiastically commented "Wow, man! You can dance to that!", and his ringing endorsement erased any lingering doubts that the band had over the song\'s suitability.<ref name="timeless4"/>

Soon after, inspired by the Beatles\' film \'\'[[A Hard Day\'s Night (film)|A Hard Day\'s Night]]\'\', the band decided to equip themselves with similar instruments to the Fab Four: a [[Rickenbacker]] [[twelve-string guitar]] for McGuinn, a [[Ludwig-Musser|Ludwig]] drum kit for Clarke, and a [[Gretsch]] Tennessean guitar for Clark (although Crosby commandeered it soon after, resulting in Clark switching to [[tambourine]]).<ref name="hjort2"/><ref>{{cite web|last=McGuinn|first=Roger|authorlink=Roger McGuinn|title=Byrds FAQ: What instruments did they play?|publisher=Roger McGuinn Home Page|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/jimmy/mcguinn/ByrdsFAQ.html#inst|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>  In October 1964, Dickson recruited [[mandolin]] player [[Chris Hillman]] as the Jet Set\'s [[bassist]].<ref>{{cite web|last=McGuinn|first=Roger|title=Byrds FAQ: How and When did they get together?|publisher=Roger McGuinn Home Page|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/jimmy/mcguinn/ByrdsFAQ.html#HowDid|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>  Hillman\'s background was more oriented towards [[country music]] than folk or rock, having been a member of the [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] groups [[the Scottsville Squirrel Barkers]], [[the Hillmen]] (also known as the Golden State Boys), and, concurrently with his recruitment into the Jet Set, the Green Grass Group.<ref name="hjort">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=21|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref name="allmusic9">{{cite web|last=Ankeny|first=Jason|title=Biography of Chris Hillman|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p1650|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-26}}</ref>

Through connections that Dickson had with [[impresario]] Benny Shapiro, and with a helpful recommendation from [[jazz]] [[trumpet]]er [[Miles Davis]], the group signed a [[recording contract]] with [[Columbia Records]] on November 10, 1964.<ref name="einarson3">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=56\xe2\x80\x9357|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>  Two weeks later, during a [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]] dinner at Eddie Tickner\'s house, the Jet Set decided to rename themselves the Byrds, a moniker that retained the theme of flight and also echoed the deliberate misspelling of "The Beatles".<ref name="einarson3"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=56\xe2\x80\x9357|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>

===Folk rock (1965\xe2\x80\x931966)===
[[File:Terry Melcher Byrds in studio 1965.jpg|300px|thumb|Producer Terry Melcher (left) in the recording studio with Gene Clark (center) and David Crosby (right). Melcher brought in session musicians to play on the "Mr. Tambourine Man" single because he felt that the Byrds hadn\'t yet gelled musically.]]
[[File:The Byrds Bob Dylan Ciro\'s.jpg|300px|thumb|Bob Dylan making an impromptu guest appearance with the Byrds at Ciro\'s nightclub.]]
{{Listen |filename=Byrds_Mr_Tambourine_Man.ogg|title=Mr. Tambourine Man|description=An excerpt from the Byrds\' cover of "[[Mr. Tambourine Man]]", highlighting the band\'s clear harmony singing and Roger McGuinn\'s jangly, twelve-string Rickenbacker guitar playing.}}
On January 20, 1965, the Byrds entered [[CBS Columbia Square|Columbia Studios]] in [[Hollywood]] to record "Mr. Tambourine Man" for release as their debut single on Columbia.<ref name="timeless3"/><ref name="hjort3">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=24|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Since the band had not yet completely gelled musically, McGuinn was the only Byrd to play on "Mr. Tambourine Man" and its Gene Clark penned [[A-side and B-side|B-side]], "[[I Knew I\'d Want You]]".<ref name="einarson3"/>  Rather than using band members, [[Record producer|producer]] [[Terry Melcher]] hired a collection of top [[session musicians]], retroactively known as [[The Wrecking Crew (music)|the Wrecking Crew]], including [[Hal Blaine]] (drums), [[Larry Knechtel]] (bass), [[Jerry Cole]] (guitar), and [[Leon Russell]] (electric piano), who (along with McGuinn on guitar) provided the instrumental backing track over which McGuinn, Crosby and Clark sang.<ref name="einarson3"/><ref name="fricke">{{cite AV media notes|title=Mr. Tambourine Man|titlelink=Mr. Tambourine Man (album)|others=The Byrds|year=1996|chapter=The Chimes of Freedom|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref>  By the time the sessions for their debut album began in March 1965, however, Melcher was satisfied that the band was competent enough to record its own musical backing.<ref name="fricke"/>  However, the use of outside musicians on the Byrds\' debut single has given rise to the persistent myth that all of the playing on their debut album was done by session musicians.<ref name="allmusic"/>

While the band waited for "Mr. Tambourine Man" to be released, they began a residency at [[Ciro\'s|Ciro\'s Le Disc]] [[nightclub]] on the [[Sunset Strip]] in Hollywood.<ref name="hjort5">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=27\xe2\x80\x9330|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  The band\'s regular appearances at Ciro\'s during March and April 1965 allowed them to hone their [[Musical ensemble|ensemble]] playing, perfect their aloof stage persona, and expand their repertoire.<ref name="hjort5"/><ref name="unterberger">{{cite book|author=Unterberger, Richie.|pages=113\xe2\x80\x93117|year=2002|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!: The \'60s Folk-Rock Revolution|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-703-X}}</ref>  In addition, it was during their residency at the nightclub that the band first began to accrue a dedicated following among L.A.\'s youth culture and hip Hollywood fraternity, with scenesters like [[Kim Fowley]], [[Peter Fonda]], [[Jack Nicholson]], [[Arthur Lee (musician)|Arthur Lee]], and [[Sonny & Cher]] regularly attending the band\'s performances.<ref name="timeless6">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=67\xe2\x80\x9370|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref><ref name="schinder">{{cite book|author=Schinder, Scott.|author2=Schwartz, Andy. |page=262|year=2007|title=Icons of Rock: An Encyclopedia of the Legends Who Changed Music Forever|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=0-313-33845-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Kubernik, Harvey.|page=84|year=2006|title=Hollywood Shack Job: Rock Music in Film and on Your Screen|publisher=University of New Mexico Press|isbn=0-8263-3542-X}}</ref>  On March 26, 1965, the author of the band\'s forthcoming debut single, Bob Dylan, made an impromptu visit to the club and joined the Byrds on stage for a rendition of [[Jimmy Reed]]\'s "[[Baby What You Want Me to Do]]".<ref name="hjort5"/>  The excitement generated by the Byrds at Ciro\'s quickly made them a must-see fixture on L.A.\'s nightclub scene and resulted in hordes of teenagers filling the [[sidewalk]]s outside the club, desperate to see the band perform.<ref name="hjort5"/>  A number of noted music historians and authors, including [[Richie Unterberger]], Ric Menck, and Peter Buckley, have suggested that the crowds of young [[Bohemianism|Bohemians]] and [[Hipster (1940s subculture)|hipsters]] that gathered at Ciro\'s to see the Byrds perform represented the first stirrings of the [[West Coast of the United States|West Coast]] [[hippie]] [[Counterculture of the 1960s|counterculture]].<ref name="buckley"/><ref name="unterberger"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Menck, Ric.|page=43|year=2007|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers (33\xe2\x85\x93 series)|publisher=Continuum Books|isbn=0-8264-1717-5}}</ref>

Columbia Records eventually released the "Mr. Tambourine Man" single on April 12, 1965.<ref name="timeless3"/>  The full, electric rock band treatment that the Byrds and producer Terry Melcher had given the song effectively created the template for the musical subgenre of [[folk rock]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Hoffmann, Frank.|page=148|year=2004|title=Encyclopedia of Recorded Sound|edition=2nd|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0-415-93835-X}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Folk Rock: An Overview|publisher=Richieunterberger.com|url=http://www.richieunterberger.com/turnover.html|accessdate=2010-03-15}}</ref>  McGuinn\'s melodic, jangling twelve-string Rickenbacker guitar playing\xe2\x80\x94which was heavily [[Dynamic range compression|compressed]] to produce an extremely bright and [[sustain]]ed tone\xe2\x80\x94was immediately influential and has remained so to the present day.<ref name="hjort3"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Kitts, Jeff.|author2=Tolinski, Brad. |page=85|year=2002|title=Guitar World Presents the 100 Greatest Guitarists of All Time|publisher=Hal Leonard|isbn=0-634-04619-5}}</ref>  The single also featured another major characteristic of the band\'s sound: their clear [[Vocal harmony|harmony singing]], which usually featured McGuinn and Clark in [[unison]], with Crosby providing the high harmony.<ref name="schinder"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Mr. Tambourine Man|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpmtm.html|accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref>  Additionally, Richie Unterberger has noted that the song\'s abstract lyrics took rock and pop songwriting to new heights; never before had such intellectual and literary wordplay been combined with rock instrumentation by a popular music group.<ref name="unterberger2">{{cite book|author=Unterberger, Richie.|page=107|year=2002|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!: The \'60s Folk-Rock Revolution|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-703-X}}</ref>

Within three months "Mr. Tambourine Man" had become the first folk rock smash [[Hit single|hit]],<ref>{{cite book|author=Dean, Maury.|page=200|year=2003|title=Rock \'n\' Roll Gold Rush: A Singles Un-Cyclopedia|publisher=Algora Publishing|isbn=0-87586-207-1}}</ref> reaching number 1 on both the U.S. [[Billboard Hot 100|\'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100]] chart and the [[UK Singles Chart]].<ref name="whitburn">{{cite book|author=Whitburn, Joel.|authorlink=Joel Whitburn|page=130|year=2008|title=Top Pop Singles 1955-2006|publisher=Record Research Inc|isbn=0-89820-172-1}}</ref><ref name="brown">{{cite book|author=Brown, Tony.|page=130|year=2000|title=The Complete Book of the British Charts|publisher=Omnibus Press|isbn=0-7119-7670-8}}</ref>  The single\'s success initiated the folk rock boom of 1965 and 1966, during which a number of Byrds-influenced acts had hits on the American and British charts.<ref name="unterberger2"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|title=Mr. Tambourine Man song review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=song|id=t1991558|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref>  The term "folk rock" was itself coined by the American music press to describe the band\'s sound in June 1965, at roughly the same time as "Mr. Tambourine Man" peaked at number 1 in the U.S.<ref>{{cite book|author=Unterberger, Richie.|page=133|year=2002|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!: The \'60s Folk-Rock Revolution|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-703-X}}</ref><ref name="timeless29">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=83\xe2\x80\x9387|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>

The \'\'[[Mr. Tambourine Man (album)|Mr. Tambourine Man]]\'\' album followed on June 21, 1965,<ref name="timeless3"/> peaking at number 6 on the [[Billboard 200|\'\'Billboard\'\' Top LPs]] chart and number 7 on the [[UK Albums Chart]].<ref name="brown"/><ref name="whitburn2">{{cite book|author=Whitburn, Joel.|page=121|year=2002|title=Top Pop Albums 1955-2001|publisher=Record Research Inc|isbn=0-89820-147-0}}</ref>  The album mixed reworkings of folk songs, including [[Pete Seeger]]\'s musical adaptation of the [[Idris Davies]]\' poem "[[The Bells of Rhymney]]", with a number of other Dylan covers and the band\'s own compositions, the majority of which were written by Gene Clark.<ref name="timeless29"/><ref name="allmusic3">{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Mr. Tambourine Man album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r3060|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref>  In particular, Clark\'s "[[I\'ll Feel a Whole Lot Better]]" has gone on to become a rock music [[Standard (music)|standard]], with many critics considering it one of the band\'s and Clark\'s best songs.<ref>{{cite book|author=Dimartino, Dave.|page=38|year=1994|title=Singer-Songwriters: Pop Music\'s Performer-Composers, from A to Zevon|publisher=Billboard Books|isbn=0-8230-7629-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Simmonds, Jeremy.|page=275|year=2008|title=The Encyclopedia of Dead Rock Stars: Heroin, Handguns, and Ham Sandwiches|publisher=Chicago Review Press|isbn=1-55652-754-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|page=65|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>  Upon release, the \'\'Mr. Tambourine Man\'\' album, like the single of the same name, was influential in popularizing folk rock<ref name="allmusic3"/> and served to establish the band as an internationally successful rock act, representing the first effective American challenge to the dominance of the Beatles and the British Invasion.<ref name="allmusic"/><ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Mr. Tambourine Man|titlelink=Mr. Tambourine Man (album)|others=The Byrds|year=1996|first=Johnny|last=Rogan|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref>

{{Listen |filename=The_Byrds_-_All_I_Really_Want_To_Do.ogg|title=All I Really Want to Do|description=A sample of the Byrds\' recording of "[[All I Really Want to Do]]", illustrating the ascending melody progression in the song\'s refrain and the Beatlesque melody used in its third verse.}}
The Byrds\' next single was "[[All I Really Want to Do]]", another interpretation of a Dylan song.<ref name="hjort4">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=39|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Despite the success of "Mr. Tambourine Man", the Byrds were reluctant to release another Dylan-penned single, feeling that it was too formulaic, but Columbia Records were insistent, believing that another Dylan cover would result in an instant hit for the group.<ref name="hjort4"/>  The Byrds\' rendition of "All I Really Want to Do" is noticeably different in structure to Dylan\'s original: it features an ascending [[melody]] progression in the [[refrain|chorus]] and utilizes a completely new melody for one of the song\'s verses, in order to turn it into a Beatlesque, [[Minor scale|minor-key]] [[Bridge (music)|bridge]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Unterberer|first=Richie|title=All I Really Want to Do song review|publisher=Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/t812832|accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref>  Issued on June 14, 1965, while "Mr. Tambourine Man" was still climbing the U.S. charts, the single was rush-released by Columbia in an attempt to bury a rival cover version that [[Cher]] had released simultaneously on [[Imperial Records]].<ref name="hjort4"/><ref name="timeless5">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=81\xe2\x80\x9382|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  A chart battle ensued, but the Byrds\' rendition stalled at number 40 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Hot 100, while Cher\'s version reached number 15.<ref name="timeless5"/>  The reverse was true in the UK, however, where the Byrds\' version reached number 4, while Cher\'s peaked at number 9.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=57|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>

Author John Einarson has noted that during this period of their career, the Byrds enjoyed tremendous popularity among teenage pop fans, with their music receiving widespread [[airplay]] on [[Contemporary hit radio|Top 40 radio]] and their faces adorning countless [[teen magazine]]s.<ref name="einarson7">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=72\xe2\x80\x9375|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>  Much was made at the time of the Byrds\' unconventional dress sense, with their casual attire strikingly at odds with the prevailing trend for uniformity among contemporary [[Beat music|beat]] groups.<ref name="timeless26">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=78\xe2\x80\x9380|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  With all five members sporting Beatlesque moptop haircuts, Crosby dressed in a striking green suede cape, and McGuinn wearing a pair of distinctive rectangular "granny glasses", the band exuded California cool, while also looking suitably non-conformist.<ref name="timeless26"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Luft, Eric V. D.|page=135|year=2009|title=Die at the Right Time!: A Subjective Cultural History of the American Sixties|publisher=Gegensatz Press|isbn=0-9655179-2-6}}</ref><ref name="scoppa">{{cite book|author=Scoppa, Bud.|page=59|year=1971|title=The Byrds|publisher=Scholastic Book Services}}</ref>  In particular, McGuinn\'s distinctive rectangular spectacles would go on to become popular among members of the burgeoning hippie counterculture in the United States.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rielly, Edward J.|page=87|year=2003|title=The 1960s|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=0-313-31261-3}}</ref>

Although McGuinn was widely regarded as the Byrds\' [[bandleader]] by this point, the band actually had multiple frontmen, with McGuinn, Clark, Crosby and later Hillman all taking turns to sing [[Lead vocalist|lead vocals]] in roughly equal measures across the group\'s repertoire.  Despite the dizzying array of personnel changes that the group underwent in later years, this lack of a dedicated lead singer would remain a stylistic trait of the Byrds\' music throughout the majority of the band\'s existence.  A further distinctive aspect of the Byrds\' image was their unsmiling air of detachment, both on stage and in front of the camera.<ref name="timeless26"/><ref name="scoppa"/>  This natural aloofness was compounded by the large amounts of [[Cannabis (drug)|marijuana]] that the band consumed and often resulted in moody and erratic [[Rock concert|live performances]].<ref name="timeless26"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=96|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Indeed, the contemporary music press was extremely critical of the Byrds\' abilities as a live act during the mid-1960s, with the reaction from the British media during the band\'s August 1965 tour of England being particularly scathing.<ref name="einarson7"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=50|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>

This 1965 English tour was largely orchestrated by the group\'s [[publicist]] [[Derek Taylor]], in an attempt to capitalize on the number 1 chart success of the "Mr. Tambourine Man" single.<ref name="einarson7"/>  Unfortunately, the tour was overhyped from the start, with the band being touted as "America\'s answer to the Beatles", a label that proved impossible for the Byrds to live up to.<ref name="einarson7"/>  During concert performances, a combination of poor sound, group illness, ragged musicianship, and the band\'s notoriously lackluster stage presence, all combined to alienate audiences and served to provoke a merciless castigating of the band in the British press.<ref name="einarson7"/>

However, the tour did enable the band to meet and socialize with a number of top English groups, including [[the Rolling Stones]] and the Beatles.<ref name="einarson7"/>  In particular, the band\'s relationship with the Beatles would prove important for both acts, with the two groups again meeting in Los Angeles some weeks later, upon the Byrds\' return to America.<ref name="einarson7"/>  During this period of fraternization, the Beatles were vocal in their support of the Byrds, publicly acknowledging them as creative competitors and naming them as their favorite American group.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lavezzoli, Peter.|page=151|year=2007|title=The Dawn of Indian music in the West|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=0-8264-2819-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Luft, Eric V. D.|page=250|year=2009|title=Die at the Right Time!: A Subjective Cultural History of the American Sixties|publisher=Gegensatz Press|isbn=0-9655179-2-6}}</ref>  A number of authors, including [[Ian MacDonald]], Richie Unterberger, and Bud Scoppa, have noted the Byrds influence on the Beatles\' late 1965 album \'\'[[Rubber Soul]]\'\',<ref>{{cite book|author=Unterberger, Richie.|page=180|year=2002|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!: The \'60s Folk-Rock Revolution|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-703-X}}</ref> most notably on the songs "[[Nowhere Man (song)|Nowhere Man]]"<ref>{{cite book|author=Scoppa, Bud.|page=29|year=1971|title=The Byrds|publisher=Scholastic Book Services}}</ref> and "[[If I Needed Someone]]", the latter of which utilizes a guitar [[riff]] similar to that in the Byrds\' cover of "The Bells of Rhymney".<ref>{{cite book|author=MacDonald, Ian.|authorlink=Ian MacDonald|page=135|year=1995|title=Revolution In The Head: The Beatles\' Records and The Sixties|publisher=Pimlico|isbn=0-7126-6208-1}}</ref>

{{Listen |filename=The_Byrds_-_Turn_Turn_Turn.ogg|title=Turn! Turn! Turn! (to Everything There Is a Season)|description=An excerpt from the Byrds\' recording of "[[Turn! Turn! Turn!|Turn! Turn! Turn! (to Everything There Is a Season)]]", which provided the band with their second U.S. number 1 single and served to cement folk rock as a chart trend.}}
For their third Columbia single, the Byrds initially intended to release a cover of Dylan\'s "[[It\'s All Over Now, Baby Blue]]" (it was even premiered on the California radio station [[KRLA]]),<ref name="timeless24">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=123\xe2\x80\x93124|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref> but instead they decided to record "[[Turn! Turn! Turn!|Turn! Turn! Turn! (to Everything There Is a Season)]]", a Pete Seeger composition with lyrics adapted almost entirely from the biblical [[Book of Ecclesiastes]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=128|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref><ref name="allmusic4">{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|title=Turn! Turn! Turn! song review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=song|id=t2736425|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-05-31}}</ref>  The song was brought to the group by McGuinn, who had previously [[Arrangement|arranged]] it in a chamber-folk style while working on folksinger [[Judy Collins]]\' 1963 album, \'\'[[Judy Collins 3 (Judy Collins album)|Judy Collins 3]]\'\'.<ref name="allmusic4"/>  The Byrds\' cover of "Turn! Turn! Turn! (to Everything There Is a Season)" was issued on October 1, 1965<ref name="timeless3"/> and became the band\'s second U.S. number 1 single, as well as the title track for their second album.<ref name="allmusic4"/>  The single represented the high-water mark of folk rock as a chart trend and has been described by music historian Richie Unterberger as "folk rock\'s highest possible grace note."<ref>{{cite book|author=Unterberger, Richie.|page=183|year=2002|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!: The \'60s Folk-Rock Revolution|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-703-X}}</ref>  In addition, music critic William Ruhlmann has noted that the song\'s lyrical message of peace and tolerance struck a nerve with the American record buying public as the [[Vietnam War]] continued to escalate.<ref name="allmusic4"/>

The Byrds\' second album, \'\'[[Turn! Turn! Turn! (album)|Turn! Turn! Turn!]]\'\', was released in December 1965<ref>{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Turn! Turn! Turn! album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r3061|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref> and while it received a mostly positive reception, critical consensus deemed it to be inferior to the band\'s debut.<ref name="hjort23">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=73\xe2\x80\x9374|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Nonetheless, it was a commercial success, peaking at number 17 on the U.S. charts and number 11 in the UK.<ref name="hjort23"/>  Author Scott Schinder has noted that, along with \'\'Mr. Tambourine Man\'\', the \'\'Turn! Turn! Turn!\'\' album served to establish the Byrds as one of rock music\'s most important creative forces, on a par with the Beatles, [[the Beach Boys]] and the Rolling Stones.<ref name="schinder2">{{cite book|author=Schinder, Scott.|author2=Schwartz, Andy. |pages=266\xe2\x80\x93267|year=2007|title=Icons of Rock: An Encyclopedia of the Legends Who Changed Music Forever|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=0-313-33845-0}}</ref>  Like their debut, the album comprised a mixture of group originals, folk songs, and Bob Dylan covers, all characterized by the group\'s clear harmonies and McGuinn\'s distinctive guitar sound.<ref>{{cite book|author=Wadhams, Wayne.|author2=Nathan, David. |page=244|year=2001|title=Inside the Hits: The Seduction of a Rock and Roll Generation|publisher=Berklee Press|isbn=0-634-01430-7}}</ref>  However, the album featured more of the band\'s own compositions than its predecessor, with Gene Clark in particular coming to the fore as a songwriter.<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!|titlelink=Turn! Turn! Turn! (album)|others=The Byrds|year=1996|first=Johnny|last=Rogan|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref>  His songs from this period, including "[[She Don\'t Care About Time]]", "The World Turns All Around Her", and "[[Set You Free This Time]]", are widely regarded by critics as among the best of the folk rock genre.<ref>{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|page=80|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Turn! Turn! Turn!|titlelink=Turn! Turn! Turn! (album)|others=The Byrds|year=1996|chapter=Turning Point: "Shindig", Scripture & "Oh! Susannah"|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref>  The latter song was even chosen for release as a single in January 1966, but its densely worded lyrics, melancholy melody, and ballad-like tempo contributed to it stalling at number 63 on the \'\'[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]\'\' chart and failing to reach the UK chart altogether.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=79|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Set You Free This Time song review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=song|id=t2736427|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-06-01}}</ref>

While the Byrds outwardly seemed to be riding the crest of a wave during the latter-half of 1965, the recording sessions for their second album had not been without tension.  One source of conflict was the power struggle that had begun to develop between producer Terry Melcher and the band\'s manager Jim Dickson, with the latter harboring aspirations to produce the band himself, causing him to be overly critical of Melcher\'s work.<ref name="timeless25">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=147\xe2\x80\x93149|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Within a month of \'\'Turn! Turn! Turn!\'\' being released, Dickson and the Byrds approached Columbia Records and requested that Melcher be replaced, despite the fact that he had successfully steered the band through the recording of two number 1 singles and two hit albums.<ref name="timeless25"/>  Any hopes that Dickson had of being allowed to produce the band himself, however, were dashed when Columbia assigned their West Coast head of [[Artists and repertoire|A&R]], Allen Stanton, to the band.<ref name="schinder2"/><ref name="timeless25"/>

===Psychedelia (1965\xe2\x80\x931967)===

On December 22, 1965, the Byrds recorded a new, self-penned composition titled "[[Eight Miles High]]" at [[RCA Records|RCA]] Studios in Hollywood.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=75|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  The song represented a creative leap forward for the band<ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Fifth Dimension|titlelink=Fifth Dimension (album)|others=The Byrds|year=1996|chapter=The New Frontier|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref> and is often considered the first full-blown [[psychedelic rock]] recording by critics, although other contemporaneous acts, such as [[Donovan]] and [[the Yardbirds]], were also exploring similar musical territory.<ref>{{cite book|author=Palmer, Robert.|page=165|year=1995|title=Rock & Roll: An Unruly History|publisher=Harmony|isbn=0-517-70050-6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Rounds, Dwight.|page=59|year=2007|title=The Year the Music Died: 1964-1972|publisher=Bridgeway Books|isbn=1-933538-69-4}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Buckley, Peter.|page=201|year=2003|title=The Rough Guide to Rock|publisher=Rough Guides|isbn=1-84353-105-4}}</ref>  The song was also pivotal in transmuting folk rock into the new musical forms of psychedelia and [[raga rock]].<ref name="einarson4">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=85\xe2\x80\x9386|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Bellman, Jonathan.|page=351|year=1997|title=The Exotic In Western Music|publisher=Northeastern Publishing|isbn=1-55553-319-1}}</ref>  However, Columbia Records refused to release the band\'s first version of the song because it had been recorded at another [[record company]]\'s studios.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=152|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  As a result, the band were forced to re-record "Eight Miles High" at Columbia Studios in Los Angeles on January 24 and 25, 1966, and it was this re-recorded version that would be released as a single and included on the group\'s third album.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=620|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref><ref name="byrdwatcher6">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Fifth Dimension|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lp5d.html|accessdate=2010-03-14}}</ref>

The song is marked by McGuinn\'s groundbreaking lead guitar playing, which saw the guitarist attempting to emulate the [[Free jazz|free form jazz]] [[saxophone]] playing of [[John Coltrane]], and in particular, Coltrane\'s playing on the song "India" from his \'\'[[Impressions (John Coltrane album)|Impressions]]\'\' album.<ref name="einarson4"/>  "Eight Miles High" also exhibits the influence of the [[Indian classical music]] of [[Ravi Shankar]] in the droning quality of the song\'s vocal melody and in McGuinn\'s guitar playing.<ref name="lavezzoli">{{cite book|author=Lavezzoli, Peter.|pages=155\xe2\x80\x93157|year=2007|title=The Dawn of Indian music in the West|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=0-8264-2819-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Crosby, David.|page=99|year=1990|title=Long Time Gone: The Autobiography of David Crosby|publisher=Mandarin Paperbacks|isbn=0-7493-0283-6}}</ref>  The song\'s subtle use of Indian influences resulted in it being labeled as "raga rock" by the [[Music journalism|music press]], but in fact, it was the single\'s B-side "[[Why (The Byrds song)|Why]]" that drew more directly on Indian [[raga]]s.<ref name="einarson4"/><ref name="lavezzoli"/>

Upon release, "Eight Miles High" was banned by many U.S. radio stations, following allegations made by the broadcasting trade journal the \'\'[[Gavin Report]]\'\', that its lyrics advocated [[Psychoactive drug#Recreational use|recreational drug use]].<ref name="timeless7">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=158\xe2\x80\x93161|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  The band and their management strenuously denied these allegations, stating that the song\'s lyrics actually described an airplane flight to London and the band\'s subsequent concert tour of England.<ref name="timeless7"/>  The relatively modest chart success of "Eight Miles High" (number 14 in the U.S. and number 24 in the UK) has been largely attributed to the broadcasting ban, although the challenging and slightly uncommercial nature of the track is another possible reason for its failure to reach the Top 10.<ref name="einarson4"/><ref name="timeless7"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=92|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>
{{Listen |filename=Byrds_-_Eight_Miles_High.ogg|title=Eight Miles High|description=An excerpt from the intro of "[[Eight Miles High]]", demonstrating the [[John Coltrane]]-influenced, free form guitar playing of Roger McGuinn.}}
In February 1966, just prior to the release of "Eight Miles High", Gene Clark left the band.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=84\xe2\x80\x9387|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  His departure was partly due to his [[fear of flying]], which made it impossible for him to keep up with the Byrds\' itinerary, and partly due to his increasing isolation within the band.<ref name="einarson5">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=87\xe2\x80\x9389|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>  Clark, who had witnessed a fatal airplane crash as a youth, had a [[panic attack]] on a plane bound for New York and as a result, he disembarked and refused to take the flight.<ref name="timeless8">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny|pages=165\xe2\x80\x93167|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  In effect, Clark\'s exit from the plane represented his exit from the Byrds, with McGuinn telling him, "If you can\'t fly, you can\'t be a Byrd."<ref name="einarson5"/>  However, it has become known in the years since the incident that there were other stress-related factors at work, as well as resentment within the band that Gene\'s songwriting income had made him the wealthiest member of the group.<ref name="einarson5"/><ref name="timeless8"/>  Clark was subsequently signed by Columbia Records as a solo artist and went on to produce a critically acclaimed but commercially unsuccessful body of work.<ref name="allmusic5"/>  He died on May 24, 1991, at the age of 46, from [[Myocardial infarction|heart failure]] brought on by a bleeding [[Peptic ulcer|stomach ulcer]], although years of [[alcohol abuse]] and a heavy [[Tobacco smoking|cigarette habit]] were also contributing factors.<ref name="allmusic5"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=313\xe2\x80\x93314|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>

The Byrds\' third album, \'\'[[Fifth Dimension (album)|Fifth Dimension]]\'\', was released in July 1966.<ref>{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Fifth Dimension album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r3062|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>  Much of the album\'s material continued to build on the band\'s new psychedelic sound, with McGuinn extending his exploration of jazz and raga styles on tracks such as "I See You" and the Crosby-penned "What\'s Happening?!?!".<ref name="byrdwatcher6"/>  The album also saw Hillman coming forward as the band\'s third vocalist, in order to fill the hole in the group\'s harmonies that Clark\'s departure had left.<ref name="byrdwatcher6"/>  The title track, "[[5D (Fifth Dimension)]]", was released as a single ahead of the album and was, like "Eight Miles High" before it, banned by a number of U.S. radio stations for supposedly featuring lyrics that advocated drug use.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=97|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref name="timeless9">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=178\xe2\x80\x93179|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  In addition, the album\'s front cover artwork featured the first appearance of the Byrds\' colorful, psychedelic [[mosaic]] logo, variations of which would subsequently appear on a number of the band\'s [[compilation album]]s, as well as on their 1967 release, \'\'[[Younger Than Yesterday]]\'\'.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|authorlink=|page=101|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965\xe2\x80\x931973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>

The \'\'Fifth Dimension\'\' album received a mixed critical reception upon release<ref name="timeless9"/> and was less commercially successful than its predecessors, peaking at number 24 in the U.S. and number 27 in the UK.<ref name="brown"/><ref name="whitburn2"/>  Band biographer Bud Scoppa has noted that with the album\'s lackluster chart performance, its lukewarm critical reception, and the high-profile loss of Gene Clark from the group, the Byrds\' popularity began to wane at this point and by late 1966, the group had been all but forgotten by the mainstream pop audience.<ref>{{cite book|author=Scoppa, Bud.|pages=54\xe2\x80\x9355|year=1971|title=The Byrds|publisher=Scholastic Book Services}}</ref>  Nonetheless, the band were considered forefathers of the emerging [[Underground music|rock underground]], with many of the new L.A. and San Francisco groups of the day, including [[Love (band)|Love]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], and the [[Buffalo Springfield]], publicly naming the Byrds as a primary influence.<ref>{{cite book|author=Scoppa, Bud.|page=64|year=1971|title=The Byrds|publisher=Scholastic Book Services}}</ref>

[[File:The Byrds Logo.jpg|230px|thumb|left|The Byrds\' psychedelic mosaic logo]]
The band returned to the studio between November 28 and December 8, 1966 to record their fourth album, \'\'[[Younger Than Yesterday]]\'\'.<ref name="timeless10">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=622\xe2\x80\x93624|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  With Allen Stanton having recently departed Columbia Records to work for [[A&M Records|A&M]], the band chose to bring in producer [[Gary Usher]] to help guide them through the album sessions.  Usher, who had a wealth of production experience and a love of innovative studio experimentation, would prove invaluable to the Byrds as they entered their most creatively adventurous phase.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=185\xe2\x80\x93186|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  The first song to be recorded for the album was the McGuinn and Hillman-penned "[[So You Want to Be a Rock \'n\' Roll Star]]", a satirical and heavily sarcastic jibe at the manufactured nature of groups like [[The Monkees]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=113|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=Younger Than Yesterday|titlelink=Younger Than Yesterday|others=The Byrds|year=1996|chapter=Fame and Misfortune: The End of the First Golden Era|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref>  The song features the [[trumpet]] playing of South African musician [[Hugh Masekela]] and as such, marks the first appearance of [[Brass instrument|brass]] on a Byrds\' recording.<ref name="byrdwatcher2">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Younger Than Yesterday|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpyty.html|accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>  "So You Want to Be a Rock \'n\' Roll Star" was issued as a single in January 1967 and peaked at number 29 in America but failed to chart in the UK.<ref name="hjort6">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=118\xe2\x80\x93120|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965\xe2\x80\x931973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Despite this relatively poor chart showing, "So You Want to Be a Rock \'n\' Roll Star" has become one of the Byrds\' best-known songs in the years since its initial release, inspiring cover versions by the likes of [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]] and [[Patti Smith|the Patti Smith Group]] amongst others.<ref>{{cite web|last=Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|title=Pack Up the Plantation: Live! album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=pack-up-the-plantation-live-r15152/review|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Ruhlmann|first=William|title=Wave album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=wave-r18302|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-11-28}}</ref>

{{Listen |filename=The_Byrds_-_Time_Between.ogg|title=Time Between|description=A sample of the country-influenced Chris Hillman composition "Time Between", which foreshadowed the Byrds\' later exploration of the [[country rock]] genre.}}
Released in February 1967, the Byrds\' fourth album, \'\'[[Younger Than Yesterday]]\'\', was more varied than its predecessor and saw the band successfully mixing psychedelia with folk rock and [[Country music|country and western]] influences.<ref name="allmusic6">{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=Younger Than Yesterday album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r3063|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-06-24}}</ref>  Although it received generally positive reviews upon its release, the album was, to a degree, overlooked by the record-buying public and consequently peaked at number 24 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' chart and number 37 on the UK Albums Chart.<ref name="hjort6"/><ref name="allmusic6"/>  However, music expert Peter Buckley has pointed out that although the album may\'ve passed the Byrds\' rapidly shrinking teen audience by, it found favor with "a new underground following who disdained hit singles, but were coming to regard albums as major artistic statements."<ref name="buckley"/>

In addition to "So You Want to Be a Rock \'n\' Roll Star", \'\'Younger Than Yesterday\'\' also includes the evocative Crosby and McGuinn penned song "Renaissance Fair", a cover of Dylan\'s "[[My Back Pages]]" (which was later released as a single), and a quartet of Chris Hillman songs, which found the bassist emerging fully formed as an accomplished songwriter.<ref name="byrdwatcher2"/><ref name="allmusic6"/>  Two of Hillman\'s country-oriented compositions on the album, "Time Between" and "The Girl with No Name", can be seen as early indicators of the [[country rock]] direction that the band would pursue on later albums.<ref name="byrdwatcher2"/>  \'\'Younger Than Yesterday\'\' also features the jazz-tinged Crosby ballad "Everybody\'s Been Burned", which critic Thomas Ward has described as "one of the most haunting songs in the Byrds\' catalogue, and one of David Crosby\'s finest compositions."<ref>{{cite web|last=Ward|first=Thomas|title=Everybody\'s Been Burned song review|publisher=Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/everybodys-been-burned-t2736514|accessdate=2011-01-20}}</ref>

By mid-1967, Jim McGuinn had changed his first name to Roger, as a result of his interest in the Indonesian religion [[Subud]], into which he had been initiated in January 1965.<ref name="timeless11">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=221\xe2\x80\x93225|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  The adoption of a new name was common among followers of the religion<ref>{{cite book|author=Lavezzoli, Peter.|page=148|year=2007|title=The Dawn of Indian music in the West|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=0-8264-2819-3}}</ref> and served to signify a spiritual rebirth for the participant.  Shortly after McGuinn\'s name change, the band entered the studio to record the Crosby-penned, non-album single "[[Lady Friend (song)|Lady Friend]]", which was released on July 13, 1967.<ref name="hjort7">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=138|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  The Byrds\' biographer [[Johnny Rogan]] has described "Lady Friend" as "a work of great maturity" and "the loudest, fastest and rockiest Byrds\' single to date."<ref name="timeless11"/>  Regardless of its artistic merits, however, the single stalled at a disappointing number 82 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' chart, despite the band making a number of high-profile television appearances to promote the record.<ref name="hjort7"/>  Crosby, who had closely overseen the recording of the song,<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=134|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Menck, Ric.|page=129|year=2007|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers (33\xe2\x85\x93 series)|publisher=Continuum Books|isbn=0-8264-1717-5}}</ref> was bitterly disappointed by the single\'s lack of success and blamed Gary Usher\'s [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]] of the song as a factor in its commercial failure.<ref name="timeless11"/>

The poor sales suffered by "Lady Friend" were in stark contrast to the chart success of the band\'s first [[compilation album]], \'\'[[The Byrds\' Greatest Hits]]\'\', which was released on August 7, 1967.<ref name="timeless11"/><ref name="hjort8">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=141\xe2\x80\x93142|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Sanctioned by Columbia Records in the wake of the Top 10 success of \'\'[[Bob Dylan\'s Greatest Hits]]\'\', the album was a critical and commercial triumph, peaking at number 6 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' Top LPs chart and giving the band their highest-charting album in America since their 1965 debut, \'\'Mr. Tambourine Man\'\'.<ref name="timeless11"/>  Within a year, the compilation would be [[RIAA certification|certified]] [[Music recording sales certification|gold]] by the [[Recording Industry Association of America]],<ref name="timeless11"/> eventually going [[Music recording sales certification|platinum]] on November 21, 1986, and is today the biggest-selling album in the Byrds\' discography.<ref name="hjort8"/><ref>{{cite web|title=The Byrds\' Greatest Hits RIAA Awards|publisher=[[Recording Industry Association of America]]|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php?resultpage=1&table=SEARCH_RESULTS&action=&title=Greatest_Hits&artist=Byrds&format=&debutLP=&category=&sex=&releaseDate=&requestNo=&type=&level=&label=&company=&certificationDate=&awardDescription=&catalogNo=&aSex=&rec_id=&charField=&gold=&platinum=&multiPlat=&level2=&certDate=&album=&id=&after=&before=&startMonth=1&endMonth=1&startYear=1958&endYear=2010&sort=Artist&perPage=25|accessdate=2010-11-01}}</ref>

Prior to the release of \'\'The Byrds\' Greatest Hits\'\', the band decided to dispense with the services of their co-managers Jim Dickson and Eddie Tickner.<ref name="hjort7"/>  The relationship between Dickson and the band had soured over recent months, and he and Tickner\'s business arrangement with the Byrds was officially dissolved on June 30, 1967.<ref name="hjort7"/>  At Crosby\'s recommendation, Larry Spector was brought in to handle the Byrds\' business affairs,<ref name="hjort7"/> with the group electing to manage themselves to a large extent.

{{Listen |filename=The_Byrds_-_Old_John_Robertson.ogg|title=Old John Robertson|description=An excerpt from the song "Old John Robertson", highlighting the Byrds\' extensive use of [[phasing]] and [[flanging]] effects on \'\'The Notorious Byrd Brothers\'\' album.}}
Between June and December 1967, the Byrds worked on completing their fifth album, \'\'[[The Notorious Byrd Brothers]]\'\'.<ref name="timeless10"/>  The lead single from the album was a cover of the [[Gerry Goffin]] and [[Carole King]] song "[[Goin\' Back]]", which was released in October 1967 and peaked at number 89 on the \'\'Billboard\'\' chart.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=149|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  Despite this lack of commercial success, the Byrds\' rendition of "Goin\' Back" featured a band performance that author Ric Menck has described as "a beautiful recording", while music critic Richie Unterberger has called it "a magnificent and melodic cover ... that should have been a big hit."<ref>{{cite web|last=Unterberger|first=Richie|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers album review|publisher=Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-notorious-byrd-brothers-r944375/review|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref><ref name="menck">{{cite book|author=Menck, Ric.|pages=91\xe2\x80\x9392|year=2007|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers (33\xe2\x85\x93 series)|publisher=Continuum Books|isbn=0-8264-1717-5}}</ref>  The song found the Byrds successfully blending their signature harmonies and chiming 12-string guitar playing with the sound of the [[pedal steel guitar]] for the first time, foreshadowing their extensive use of the instrument on their next album, \'\'[[Sweetheart of the Rodeo]]\'\'.<ref name="menck"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Deming|first=Mark|title=Goin\' Back song review|publisher=Allmusic|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/t1559938|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref>

Released in January 1968, \'\'The Notorious Byrd Brothers\'\' album saw the band taking their psychedelic experimentation to its furthest extremes by mixing folk rock, country music, jazz, and psychedelia (often within a single song), while utilizing innovative studio production techniques such as [[phasing]] and [[flanging]].<ref name="byrdwatcher3">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpnbb.html|accessdate=2010-06-25}}</ref><ref name="fricke2">{{cite AV media notes|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers|titlelink=The Notorious Byrd Brothers|others=The Byrds|year=1997|chapter=The End of the Innocence|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|page=152|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  The album featured contributions from a number of noted session musicians, including [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] guitarist and future Byrd, [[Clarence White]].<ref name="timeless13">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=237\xe2\x80\x93238|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  White, who had also played on \'\'Younger Than Yesterday\'\',<ref name="byrdwatcher3"/> contributed country-influenced guitar to the tracks "Natural Harmony", "Wasn\'t Born to Follow" and "Change Is Now".<ref name="timeless10"/>  Upon release, the album was almost universally praised by music critics but it was only moderately successful commercially, particularly in the United States where it peaked at number 47.<ref>{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=157\xe2\x80\x93158|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref>  However, the album\'s reputation has grown over the years and today it is widely regarded by critics and fans as one of the Byrds\' best album releases.<ref name="fricke2"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Olsen|first=Bob|title=The Byrds \xe2\x80\x93 The Notorious Byrd Brothers SACD review|publisher=Music Tap|url=http://www.musictap.net/Reviews/ByrdsNotoriousByrdBrosSACD.html|accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref>

===Line-up changes (1967\xe2\x80\x931968)===
While the band worked on \'\'[[The Notorious Byrd Brothers]]\'\' album throughout late 1967, there was increasing tension and acrimony between the members of the group, which eventually resulted in the departures of both Crosby and Clarke.<ref name="byrdwatcher3"/><ref name="fricke2"/>  McGuinn and Hillman became increasingly irritated by what they saw as Crosby\'s overbearing egotism and his attempts to dictate the band\'s musical direction.<ref name="timeless11"/><ref name="timeless12">{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=232\xe2\x80\x93234|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  In addition, during the Byrds\' performance at the [[Monterey Pop Festival]] on June 17, 1967, Crosby gave lengthy in-between-song speeches on controversial subjects, including the [[John F. Kennedy assassination|JFK assassination]] and the benefits of giving [[LSD]] to "all the statesmen and politicians in the world", to the intense annoyance of the other band members.<ref>{{cite book|author=Selvin, Joel.|authorlink=Joel Selvin|page=54|year=1992|title=Monterey Pop|publisher=Chronicle Books|isbn=0-8118-0153-5}}</ref>  He further irritated his bandmates by performing with rival group [[Buffalo Springfield]] at Monterey, filling in for ex-member [[Neil Young]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Menck, Ric.|page=75|year=2007|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers (33\xe2\x85\x93 series)|publisher=Continuum Books|isbn=0-8264-1717-5}}</ref>  His reputation within the band deteriorated even more following the commercial failure of "Lady Friend", the first Byrds\' single to feature a song penned solely by Crosby on its [[A-side and B-side|A-side]].<ref name="timeless11"/><ref name="hjort7"/>

{{quote box|width=23em|"They came over and said that they wanted to throw me out. They came zooming up in their Porsches and said that I was impossible to work with and I wasn\'t very good anyway and they\'d do better without me. And frankly, I\'ve been laughing ever since. Fuck \'em. But it hurt like hell. I didn\'t try to reason with them. I just said, \'it\'s a shameful waste ... goodbye.\'"|\xe2\x80\x94David Crosby talking in 1980 about the day Roger McGuinn and Chris Hillman fired him from the Byrds.<ref name="timeless12"/>}}
Tensions within the band finally erupted in August 1967, during recording sessions for \'\'The Notorious Byrd Brothers\'\' album, when Michael Clarke quit the group over disputes with his bandmates and his dissatisfaction with the material that the songwriting members of the band were providing.<ref name="allmusic7"/><ref name="hjort9">{{cite book|author=Hjort, Christopher.|pages=143\xe2\x80\x93146|year=2008|title=So You Want To Be A Rock \'n\' Roll Star: The Byrds Day-By-Day (1965-1973)|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=1-906002-15-0}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|page=228|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>  Session drummers [[Jim Gordon (musician)|Jim Gordon]] and [[Hal Blaine]] were brought in to temporarily replace Clarke in the studio, although he continued to honor his live concert commitments with the group.<ref name="allmusic7"/><ref name="hjort9"/>  Then, in September, Crosby refused to participate in the recording of the [[Gerry Goffin|Goffin]]\xe2\x80\x93[[Carole King|King]] song "[[Goin\' Back]]",<ref name="hjort9"/> considering it to be inferior to his own "[[Triad (The Byrds song)|Triad]]", a controversial song about a [[m\xc3\xa9nage \xc3\xa0 trois]] that was in direct competition with "Goin\' Back" for a place on the album.<ref name="fricke2"/>  Crosby felt that the band should rely on self-penned material for their albums, rather than cover songs by other artists and writers.<ref name="menck2">{{cite book|author=Menck, Ric.|pages=80\xe2\x80\x9382|year=2007|title=The Notorious Byrd Brothers (33\xe2\x85\x93 series)|publisher=Continuum Books|isbn=0-8264-1717-5}}</ref>  He would eventually give "Triad" to the San Francisco band [[Jefferson Airplane]], who included a recording of it on their 1968 album, \'\'[[Crown of Creation]]\'\'.<ref name="hjort9"/><ref>{{cite web|last=Eder|first=Bruce|title=Crown of Creation album review|publisher=Allmusic|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r10298|pure_url=yes}}|accessdate=2010-06-27}}</ref>

Tensions reached a breaking point during October 1967, when McGuinn and Hillman drove to Crosby\'s home and fired him, stating that they would be better off without him.<ref name="timeless12"/>  Crosby subsequently received a cash settlement, with which he bought a [[sailboat]]<ref name="timeless12"/> and soon after, he began working with [[Stephen Stills]] and [[Graham Nash]] in the successful [[Supergroup (music)|supergroup]] [[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young|Crosby, Stills & Nash]].<ref name="crosby">{{cite web|title=David Crosby: Bio|publisher=David Crosby Home Page|url=http://www.davidcrosby.com/bio|accessdate=2012-04-03}}</ref>  In the years since his exit from the Byrds, Crosby has enjoyed an influential and commercially successful career as a part of Crosby, Stills & Nash (sometimes augmented by [[Neil Young]]), [[Crosby & Nash]], [[CPR (band)|CPR]], and as a solo artist.<ref name="crosby"/>  During the 1980s, he fought against crippling [[Substance dependence|drug addiction]] and eventually served a year in prison on drug-related charges.<ref name="crosby"/>  He emerged from jail free of his drug habit and remains musically active up to the present day.<ref name="allmusic13"/>

Following Crosby\'s departure, Gene Clark briefly rejoined the band, but left just three weeks later, after again refusing to board an aircraft while on tour.<ref name="einarson6">{{cite book|author=Einarson, John.|pages=126\xe2\x80\x93127|year=2005|title=Mr. Tambourine Man: The Life and Legacy of the Byrds\' Gene Clark|publisher=Backbeat Books|isbn=0-87930-793-5}}</ref>  There is some disagreement among biographers and band historians as to whether Clark actually participated in the recording sessions for \'\'The Notorious Byrd Brothers\'\', but there is evidence to suggest that he sang [[Backing vocalist|backing vocals]] on the songs "Goin\' Back" and "Space Odyssey".<ref name="menck2"/><ref name="einarson6"/>  Michael Clarke also returned to the band briefly, towards the end of the album sessions, before being informed by McGuinn and Hillman that he was once again an ex-member.<ref name="timeless13"/>

Now reduced to a duo, McGuinn and Hillman elected to hire new band members.  Hillman\'s cousin [[Kevin Kelley (musician)|Kevin Kelley]] was quickly recruited as the band\'s new drummer<ref name="fricke3">{{cite AV media notes|title=Sweetheart of the Rodeo|titlelink=Sweetheart of the Rodeo|others=The Byrds|year=1997|chapter=A Trip to the Country|first=David|last=Fricke|type=CD booklet|publisher=Columbia/Legacy}}</ref> and the [[Trio (music)|trio]] embarked on an early 1968 college tour in support of \'\'The Notorious Byrd Brothers\'\'.<ref name="byrdwatcher4">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Gram Parsons - The Byrds: 1968|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/memgrp3.html|accessdate=2010-07-20}}</ref>  It soon became apparent, however, that recreating the band\'s studio recordings with a three-piece line-up wasn\'t going to be possible and so, McGuinn and Hillman, in a fateful decision for their future career direction, hired [[Gram Parsons]] as a [[Keyboard instrument|keyboard]] player, although he quickly moved to guitar.<ref name="byrdwatcher4"/><ref name="byrdwatcher5">{{cite web|last=Connors|first=Tim|title=Sweetheart of the Rodeo|publisher=ByrdWatcher: A Field Guide to the Byrds of Los Angeles|url=http://ebni.com/byrds/lpsotr.html|accessdate=2010-07-20}}</ref>  Although Parsons and Kelley were both considered full members of the Byrds, they actually received a salary from McGuinn and Hillman, and did not sign with Columbia Records when the Byrds\' recording contract was renewed on February 29, 1968.<ref>{{cite book|author=Rogan, Johnny.|pages=253\xe2\x80\x93254|year=1998|title=The Byrds: Timeless Flight Revisited|edition=2nd|publisher=Rogan House|isbn=0-9529540-1-X}}</ref>

===Country rock (1968\xe2\x80\x931973)===

====The Gram Parsons era====
Following his induction into the band, [[Gram Parsons]] began to assert his own musical agenda in which he intended to marry his love of [[Country music|country and western]] music with youth culture\'s passion for rock and in doing so, make country music fashionable for a young audience.<ref name="byrdwatcher5"/><ref>{{cite AV media notes|title=GP/Grievous Angel|others=[[Gram Parsons]]|year=1990|first=Marley|last=Brant|type=CD booklet|publisher=[[Reprise Records]]}}</ref>  He found a kindred spirit in Hillman, who had played mandolin in a number of notable [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] bands before joining the Byrds.<ref name="byrdwatcher5"/>  In addition, Hillman had also persuaded the Byrds to incorporate subtle country influences into their music in the past, beginning with the song "[[A Satisfied Mind|Satisfied Mind]]" on the \'\'Turn! Turn!
